For the status conference on January 14, 2021, at 10:00 a.m., each party should designate a lead counsel to speak at the conference by emailing the name of their lead counsel to Judge Donato's Courtroom Deputy, Ms. Lisa Clark, at jdcrd@cand.uscourts.gov by January 13, 2021, at 3:00 p.m. California time. The names for lead counsel are needed so that they can be identified during the Zoom hearing when the case is called. All lead counsel must call in fifteen minutes before the hearing to test internet, video, and audio capabilities. All counsel, parties, members of the public, and press may join the webinar using the link or information below: https://cand-uscourts.zoomgov.com/j/1617171523?pwd=VWJqM2ZYT1UvNFZ0ZHNZUUhGWTBCZz09 Webinar ID: 161 717 1523 Password: 213597 Or iPhone one-tap : US: +16692545252,,1617171523#,,1#,213597# or +16468287666,,1617171523#,,1#,213597# Or Telephone: Dial (for higher quality, dial a number based on your current location): US: +1 669 254 5252 or +1 646 828 7666PLEASE NOTE: Persons granted remote access to court proceedings are reminded of the general prohibition against photographing, recording, and rebroadcasting of court proceedings (including those held by telephone or videoconference). See General Order 58 at Paragraph III. Any recording of a court proceeding held by video or teleconference, including "screen-shots" or other visual copying of a hearing, is absolutely prohibited. Violation of these prohibitions may result in sanctions, including removal of court-issued media credentials, restricted entry to future hearings, or any other sanctions deemed necessary by the court. ORDER. Presidential Proclamation 10141, "Ending Discriminatory Bans on Entry to the United States," 86 Fed. Reg. 7005 (2021), revokes Presidential Proclamation 9645 and requires, among other things, plans within 45 days to ensure (i) that individuals whose immigrant visa applications were denied under PP 9645 "may have their applications reconsidered," and (ii) "that visa applicants are not prejudiced as a result of a previous visa denial" due to PP 9645. Plaintiffs in these related cases acknowledge that the new Proclamation's requirements, if carried out by the government, may remedy the harms plaintiffs have alleged in these cases. See Emami Dkt. Nos. 173, 175. The Court consequently finds it appropriate to stay these cases, terminate the pending discovery disputes, and administratively close the cases, pending further developments. The parties are directed to file a joint status update by June 7, 2021. Signed by Judge James Donato on 3/23/2021. (This is a text-only entry generated by the court. There is no document associated with this entry.) (jdlc2S, COURT STAFF) (Filed on 3/23/2021) (Entered: 03/23/2021)

ORDER. These related cases -- Emami, No. 18-cv-1587-JD & Pars, No. 18-cv-7818-JD -- are reopened, and the previously-imposed stays are lifted. Defendants' request to dismiss the cases as moot is denied without prejudice, as the Court finds the request is not sufficiently supported by the record at this point. Plaintiffs may file their motion for summary judgment whenever they wish to do so, and the parties are directed to meet and confer on a briefing schedule. The briefing must be coordinated and streamlined as between the two related cases; duplicative briefs will not be accepted. Defendants may renew any mootness arguments in their opposition to plaintiffs' summary judgment motion, as warranted. The parties are further directed to file a stipulation of dismissal for those petitioner-plaintiffs as to whom the parties agree there is no live controversy. See Dkt. No. 89-1. Signed by Judge James Donato on 3/15/2022. (This is a text-only entry generated by the court. There is no document associated with this entry.) (jdlc2, COURT STAFF) (Filed on 3/15/2022) (Entered: 03/15/2022)

CLERK'S NOTICE. The summary judgment hearing set for July 28, 2022, at 10:00 a.m. before Judge James Donato will be held by Zoom Webinar. All counsel, parties, members of the public, and press may join the webinar by clicking the link or using the information below. Lead counsel are requested to call in fifteen minutes before the hearing to test internet, video, and audio capabilities: https://cand-uscourts.zoomgov.com/j/1617171523?pwd=VWJqM2ZYT1UvNFZ0ZHNZUUhGWTBCZz09Webinar ID: 161 717 1523 Password: 213597 Or iPhone one-tap : US: +16692545252,,1617171523#,,1#,213597# or +16468287666,,1617171523#,,1#,213597# Or Telephone: Dial (for higher quality, dial a number based on your current location): US: +1 669 254 5252 or +1 646 828 7666PLEASE NOTE: Persons granted remote access to court proceedings are reminded of the general prohibition against photographing, recording, and rebroadcasting of court proceedings (including those held by telephone or videoconference). See General Order 58 at Paragraph III. Any recording of a court proceeding held by video or teleconference, including screen-shots or other visual copying of a hearing, is absolutely prohibited. Violation of these prohibitions may result in sanctions, including removal of court-issued media credentials, restricted entry to future hearings, or any other sanctions deemed necessary by the court. Please see https://www.cand.uscourts.gov/zoom for information on preparing for and participating in a Zoom Webinar. (This is a text-only entry generated by the court. There is no document associated with this entry.) (jdlc2, COURT STAFF) (Filed on 7/26/2022) (Entered: 07/26/2022)

No. 206 in Case No. 18-1587.Each party or party group is requested to designate a lead counsel to speak at the hearing by emailing the name of their lead counsel to the Court's Courtroom Deputy, Ms. Lisa Clark, at jdcrd@cand.uscourts.gov by Thursday, August 11, 2022, at 3:00 p.m. California time. case_data.name: Emami v. Nielsen
case_data.plaintiff_description: A putative class of (originally 26) individuals who had been denied a travel visa, or whose relatives had been denied a travel visa as a result of President Trump's "Travel Ban" executive orders.
special_collections: Trump Administration 1.0: Challenges to the Government
case_data.summary:
This is one of many legal challenges to the series of Trump's executive orders (EOs) known collectively as the "Travel Ban" or "Muslim Ban." This suit in particular challenged the waiver system that accompanied the ban, which was purportedly instated to prevent the EOs from arbitrarily denying people entry into the country.

Twenty six individuals who had been denied a travel visa, or whose relatives had been denied a travel visa as a result of the EOs, filed this putative class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California (in San Francisco) on March 13, 2018. District Judge James Donato was assigned to the case. The plaintiffs sued the President; the U.S. Attorney General; the Department of Justice; the Secretary and Department of Homeland Security; the Secretary of State and the State Department; and the Director of National Intelligence along with the Office of the Director of National Intelligence. Plaintiffs brought this case against defendants under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), alleging defendants violated the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment and the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA). The plaintiffs, represented by the Immigrant Advocacy and Litigation Center, Public Counsel, and private counsel, sought injunctive and declaratory relief.

The plaintiffs alleged that the Trump Administration's failure to grant visas to individuals because of their nationality was unconstitutional. They argued the resulting separation of U.S. citizens and lawful permanent residents from their families was in contravention of Congress' purpose in the INA—promoting family reunification. Therefore, the government's actions amounted to an arbitrary and capricious act in violation of the APA.

The plaintiffs also argued that the government's refusal to consider applicants' eligibility for waivers on a case-by-case basis or develop meaningful guidance was, as a matter of law, arbitrary and capricious and therefore a violation of the APA. The plaintiffs further alleged that the government targeted individuals with discriminatory intent based on national origin without any lawful justification in violation of the Due Process and Equal Protection guarantees of the Fifth Amendment. First, the plaintiffs cited the lack of a provision for waivers coupled with the government’s blanket denials of visas to applicants targeted by EOs. Second, the plaintiffs cited statements made by government officials concerning their intent and the application of the travel ban. As a result, the plaintiffs asked the court to order the government to consider the plaintiffs' eligibility for waivers.

The plaintiffs requested the certification of two classes: "Family Member Class" and "Visa Applicant Class." The Family Member Class was defined as US citizens and permanent residents "with approved family-based visa petitions or whose family members have applied for visa categories covered by the ban, and whose family members have been or will be refused pursuant to the Proclamation without an opportunity to apply for and be meaningfully considered for a waiver or are awaiting adjudication of a waiver." The Visa Applicant Class is defined as "Iranian, Libyan, Somali, Syrian, and Yemeni nationals who have applied for immigrant or nonimmigrant visas that have been or will be refused pursuant to the Proclamation without an opportunity to apply for and be meaningfully considered for a waiver or are awaiting adjudication of a waiver."

The plaintiffs filed their first amended complaint on July 29, 2018, and the government moved to dismiss the complaint for failure to state a claim on September 12, 2018. On February 4, 2019, the court denied the motion to dismiss for the APA claim and granted the motion for the Fifth Amendment and mandamus claims. For the Fifth Amendment due process claim, the court held that the plaintiffs failed to allege any constitutionally protected right for either plaintiff class. The court found that the equal protection claim assumed the EOs unconstitutionally excluded Muslims or illegally discriminated on the basis of nationality, but that the Supreme Court had already decided that these travel orders passed rational basis review in Trump v. Hawaii. Based on this precedent, the district court held that the government’s national security justification for the EOs was sufficient to stand against an equal protection challenge. Lastly, the court dismissed the mandamus claim because the APA claim would go forward and therefore plaintiffs would not have exhausted all other avenues for relief to make a writ of mandamus appropriate. 365 F. Supp. 3d 1009.

The plaintiffs filed their second amended complaint on February 23, 2019. On February 26, 2019, the government moved to consolidate this case with Pars Equality Center v. Pompeo. After oral argument on April 11, 2019, the court denied the motion and decided to allow both cases to proceed, ordering the parties to work together to minimize duplication between the two cases.

In response to the second amended complaint, the government filed a motion to dismiss or obtain summary judgment on June 13, 2019. The motion argued the complaint should be dismissed for failure to state an actionable claim and that the existing waiver process was “not a sham” but rather an adequate procedure for the handling of thousands of visa applications.

A contentious period of discovery ensued throughout the rest of 2019 and into 2020. During this time, two plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed their claims on October 30, 2019.

On June 5, 2020, the court granted in part and denied in part the motion to dismiss following the same reasoning and outcome from the February 4, 2019, order that addressed the first amended complaint. The motion to dismiss was denied for the APA claim and granted for the Fifth Amendment and mandamus claims. In addition, the court denied summary judgment and denied the opportunity for another round of pleading amendments. 365 F. Supp. 3d. 1009.

Discovery continued through 2020. But the EOs at issue were revoked by Joe Biden on his first day in office, January 20, 2021. This revocation was announced by way of Proclamation 10141 which also ordered the State Department to resume processing visa applications from people affected by the EOs. The Proclamation instructed the Secretary of State to provide a report including the number of visa applicants being considered for a waiver of the Travel Ban EOs’ restrictions, a plan for “expeditiously adjudicating” these applications, a proposal to ensure the reconsideration of denied applications under the revoked EOs, and a plan to ensure that the cases of re-applicants were not to be prejudiced as a result of a previous visa denial resulting from the revoked EOs.

This change in executive policy prompted mootness rulings and withdrawals of claims in other actions arising out of the implementation of the EOs. On February 11, 2021, the government filed a notice to the district court informing it of two mootness rulings issued by the Ninth and Sixth Circuits on appeals from travel ban litigation following Biden’s inauguration day proclamation. (One of the cases they cited in this notice, Arab American Civil Rights League v. Trump, can be found here in the Clearinghouse.) In addition to notifying the court of these appellate decisions, the government asked the district court to dismiss the case.

Instead of dismissing the lawsuit on March 23, 2020, the court stayed proceedings pending DHS’ execution of President Biden’s January 20 Proclamation. The court also directed the parties to file a joint status update by June 7, 2021.

The parties filed their joint update on June 7, 2021. In the update, the parties explained why they had not reached a settlement. The plaintiffs claimed, among other things, that following the January 20 proclamation, the government invited them to reapply for visas, denying them the benefit of their earlier application date. On the other side, the government claimed that because the Proclamation undid the EOs that were the source of the harm experienced by the plaintiffs, that there was no live case or controversy for the district court to adjudicate.

On June 16, 2021, District Judge Donato set a status conference for September 2, 2021. The plaintiffs moved to lift the stay of proceedings on July 13, 2021, and the government filed its opposition to this motion on July 27, 2021.  On September 2, the court held a status conference and, on October 4, the parties filed a joint submission outlining their respective stances regarding which plaintiff's still had live claims.

On March 15, 2022, the court ordered that this case and Pars Equality Center be reopened. Defendants' request to dismiss the cases for mootness was denied without prejudice because of the application date issue raised by the plaintiffs. The parties were also instructed to file a stipulation of dismissal for any plaintiffs whom the parties agreed were not involved in any live controversy.

The case is ongoing.
case_data.summary_short: On March 13, 2018, 26 individuals who had been denied travel visas, or had relatives denied a travel visa under Donald Trump's "Travel Ban" sued the federal government. They claimed that denying individuals' travel visas because of their national origin was unconstitutional and violated federal law. President Biden revoked the “Travel Ban” and ordered that visa applications resume processing on January 20, 2021. In a joint status update filed on June 7, 2021, the parties explained why they had not reached a settlement. The plaintiffs claimed that following the January 20 proclamation from President Biden, the government invited them to reapply for visas, denying them the benefit of their earlier application date. On the other side, the government claimed that because the Proclamation undid the EOs that were the source of the harm experienced by plaintiffs, that there is no live case or controversy for the district court to adjudicate. The case is ongoing.
case_data.summary_tiny: Settlement negotiations are ongoing in this federal lawsuit against @DHSgov concerning the waiver system put in place for the #TrumpTravelBan despite the fact that @POTUS rescinded Trump's EOs on 1/20/21.

ee 17  As a second claim, the Pars plaintiffs essentially re-allege their first claim in the 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  alternative, this time under the “Accardi Doctrine & Administrative Procedure Act.”  Dkt. No. 1 
19  (Pars) ¶¶ 289-94.  It will go forward for the reasons stated in the Emami order with respect to the 
20  Accardi doctrine.  The government says that “Accardi has no relevance here, where the 
21  Proclamation and its related guidance are neither regulations nor internal documents that create 
22  any procedural rights.”  Dkt. No. 120 (Pars) at 10.  This is in effect an improper request for 
23  reconsideration of the Emami order, see Civil L.R. 7-9, and in any event, the Accardi doctrine is 
24  not so circumscribed, as the government’s own case citations demonstrate.  In Montilla v. 
25  Immigration and Naturalization Service, 926 F.2d 162, 167 (2d Cir. 1991), the court held that 
26  “[t]he Accardi doctrine is premised on fundamental notions of fair play underlying the concept of 
27  due process.  . . . Its ambit is not limited to rules attaining the status of formal regulations.  As the 
28  Supreme Court noted ‘where the rights of individuals are affected, it is incumbent upon agencies 
5 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 152   Filed 06/05/20   Page 6 of 10
 
1  to follow their own procedures.’”  The Montilla court further noted that “[t]he doctrine has 
2  continued vitality, particularly where a petitioner’s rights are ‘affected.’”  Id. 
3  Two other aspects of the Montilla case are relevant here.  It does not stand for the 
4  proposition, as the government suggests, that “even assuming that an Accardi claim could survive 
5  a motion to dismiss, the only relief available would be limited to a ‘remand’ with instructions for 
6  the agency to comply.”  Dkt. No. 120 (Pars) at 11.  In Montilla, a remand to the Board of 
7  Immigration Appeals made sense because petitioner’s sole contention on appeal was that “the 
8  immigration judge did not follow the applicable regulation protecting an alien’s right to counsel, 8 
9  C.F.R. § 242.16(a) (1990), and that this error constituted a denial of due process” in his 
10  deportation proceeding.  926 F.2d at 166, 170.  The Montilla court never said that a remand was 
11  the only option for an Accardi violation; to the contrary, it emphasized that the doctrine was “still 
12  alive and well” and that it was a “judicially-evolved rule ensuring fairness.”  Id. at 168.  This 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  underscores the flexibility inherent in the doctrine to fashion a remedy that fits the wrong.  
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  Montilla is also notable for applying Accardi as a freestanding claim, untethered to the 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  APA or other statute.  This is entirely consistent with the decision in Accardi itself, which was not 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  based on the APA.  See United States ex rel. Accardi v. Shaughnessy, 347 U.S. 260 (1954).  The 
S d nr
ee 17  Court has reached the same conclusion as Montilla that an Accardi claim can stand on its own and 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  “is at heart a claim of procedural fairness that owes as much to the Due Process Clause as to the 
19  Administrative Procedures Act.”  Dkt. No. 122 (Emami) at 2 (citing Jefferson v. Harris, 285 F. 
20  Supp. 3d 173, 185 (D.D.C. 2018)).  Plaintiffs’ decision to tie their Accardi claim to the APA is 
21  analytically questionable, and they may find that they have imposed on themselves unnecessary 
22  burdens by doing that.  The request to dismiss the Pars plaintiffs’ second claim under the Accardi 
23  doctrine is denied.   
24  4.  Fifth Amendment Due Process Claim 
25  Plaintiffs’ third claim directly under the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment for a 
26  violation of procedural due process cannot go forward.  In the Emami order, the Court dismissed 
27  this claim due to plaintiffs’ “inability to allege a deprivation of an interest protected by the Due 
28  Process Clause.”  Dkt. No. 74 (Emami) at 17.  This is a separate and different inquiry from the one 
6 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 152   Filed 06/05/20   Page 7 of 10
 
1  under Accardi, and is subject to different standards.  The Pars plaintiffs ask the Court to 
2  “reconsider its view,” Dkt. No. 125 (Pars) at 12, on the basis of a circuit decision from 2008.  See 
3  id. at 12-13 (citing Bustamante v. Mukasey, 531 F.3d 1059 (9th Cir. 2008)).  This is also an 
4  improper request for reconsideration, and it is unpersuasive in that Bustamante pre-dates Kerry v. 
5  Din, 135 S.Ct. 2128 (2015), the main basis for the Court’s prior order on this issue, by nearly a 
6  decade.  The third claim is dismissed.   
7  B.  Emami Second Amended Complaint 
8  The second amended complaint in Emami, and the attendant motion to dismiss arguments, 
9  are Groundhog Day or déjà vu all over again, depending on one’s taste in clichés.  The allegations 
10  and arguments on both sides are virtually unchanged.  
11  The Emami SAC continues to suffer from vague and conflicting allegations.  To take one 
12  example, the SAC says that defendants have failed to issue any guidance at all.  See, e.g., Dkt. No. 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  75 (Emami) ¶ 313 (“Defendants have either failed to promulgate guidance or have promulgated 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  guidance that is arbitrary and capricious on its face”).  This is an inherently odd assertion, 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  especially in light of plaintiffs’ own complaint exhibits in which the State Department recognized 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  its online postings as its “outward facing guidance” for waivers.  Dkt. No. 74 (Emami) at 14.  
S d nr
ee 17  Plaintiffs try to walk this back in their opposition to the motion to dismiss, where they say that 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  their claim “is not that no guidance has been issued at all, but rather that the issued guidance has 
19  not been followed; that the guidance itself is arbitrary and capricious; and that it violates 
20  Plaintiffs’ constitutional rights.”  Dkt. No. 104 (Emami) at 1-2.  In light of this admission, the 
21  portions and claims in the SAC alleging that no guidance was issued are dismissed.  The Court 
22  will not catalog here the other vague and inconsistent allegations in the SAC, but if they become 
23  an issue in the case, they are likely to meet a similar disposition. 
24  The government’s request to dismiss the first claim under the APA is denied.  Plaintiffs 
25  allege, among other things, that the government has “failed to follow their own policies and 
26  procedures,” and have “put in place a waiver process in which applicants are denied waivers 
27  without ever receiving notice or an opportunity to apply [and] applicants are denied waivers 
28  without having had a consular interview since the time the Proclamation went into effect.”  Dkt. 
7 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 152   Filed 06/05/20   Page 8 of 10
 
1  No. 75 (Emami) ¶ 314.  Plaintiffs allege that these actions should be invalidated under Accardi, 
2  347 U.S. 260.  Id. ¶ 317.  The Court has already found this to be a viable claim, Dkt. No. 74 
3  (Emami), and that conclusion holds.  
4  The second and third claims for relief under the Fifth Amendment are again dismissed 
5  based on an “inability to allege a deprivation of an interest protected by the Due Process Clause.”  
6  Dkt. No. 74 (Emami) at 17.  The Court has also determined that the equal protection claim “holds 
7  together only if it is assumed that the Proclamation unconstitutionally excludes Muslims or 
8  illegally discriminates on the basis of nationality, a proposition that the Supreme Court turned 
9  aside in Hawaii.”  Id. (citing 138 S.Ct. at 2413-23).  The Court further noted that the equal 
10  protection claim was likely to be subject to rational basis review, and that the Supreme Court “has 
11  already concluded in reviewing the Proclamation that ‘the Government has set forth a sufficient 
12  national security justification to survive rational basis review.’  Hawaii, 138 S.Ct. at 2423.”  Id. at 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  18.  The Emami plaintiffs’ Fifth Amendment claims are virtually unchanged from their previous 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  versions, and the Court sees no reason to reach a different conclusion on either claim. 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  The mandamus claim is dismissed.  The claim focuses on defendants’ alleged “fail[ure] to 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  develop meaningful guidance,” Dkt. No. 75 (Emami) ¶ 336, an allegation that plaintiffs have now 
S d nr
ee 17  retracted.  Plaintiffs have added a claim for unreasonable delay on decisions on individual visa and 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  waiver applications.  Id. ¶ 337.  But “[m]andamus is an extraordinary remedy and is available to 
19  compel a federal official to perform a duty only if: (1) the individual’s claim is clear and certain; 
20  (2) the official’s duty is nondiscretionary, ministerial, and so plainly prescribed as to be free from 
21  doubt, and (3) no other adequate remedy is available.”  Kildare v. Saenz, 325 F.3d 1078, 1084 (9th 
22  Cir. 2003); see also Heckler v. Ringer, 466 U.S. 602, 616 (1984) (“The common-law writ of 
23  mandamus, as codified in 28 U.S.C. § 1361, is intended to provide a remedy for a plaintiff only if 
24  he has exhausted all other avenues of relief and only if the defendant owes him a clear 
25  nondiscretionary duty.”).  Plaintiffs do not identify any source of law that mandates that decisions 
26  be issued within a certain period of time, and the decisions on individual waiver applications are 
27  inherently discretionary.  See 82 Fed. Reg. at 45168 (“a consular officer, or the Commissioner, 
28 
8 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 152   Filed 06/05/20   Page 9 of 10
 
1  United States Customs and Border Protection (CBP), or the Commissioners’ designee, as 
2  appropriate, may, in their discretion, grant waivers on a case-by-case basis”). 
3  II.  SUMMARY JUDGMENT 
4  The government’s motions for summary judgment are denied.  The government relies on 
5  an “administrative record” to “show[] that defendants have applied the waiver provision in an 
6  orderly way.”  Dkt. No. 98 (Emami) at 11.  But this does not account for the Accardi claims, and 
7  “there is no ‘administrative record’ when the essence of the claim is that the government has failed 
8  to act in accordance with its own rules and regulations.”  Dkt. No. 122 (Emami) at 2.  In addition, 
9  the multiple discovery dispute letters that have been filed in these cases underscore the degree to 
10  which the parties disagree about the material facts and what the “administrative record” might 
11  properly contain.  These factual disputes preclude summary judgment at this time.  See Federal 
12  Trade Commission v. D-Link Systems, Inc., No. 17-cv-00039-JD, 2018 WL 6040192 (N.D. Cal. 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  Nov. 5, 2018).  It is also doubtful that plaintiffs have had a full and fair opportunity to take 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  discovery from defendants and test the evidence the government has presented as the 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  administrative record.   
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  CONCLUSION 
S d nr
ee 17  In the Pars case, defendants’ motion to dismiss is denied as to plaintiffs’ APA claim and 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  Accardi claim, but granted as to the Fifth Amendment claim.  The summary judgment motion is 
19  denied without prejudice.   
20  In the Emami case, defendants’ motion to dismiss is denied for plaintiffs’ APA claim, but 
21  granted for plaintiffs’ Fifth Amendment Due Process and Equal Protection claims, and the 
22  mandamus claim.  Defendants’ summary judgment motion is denied without prejudice.   
23  On this record, the Court declines to provide yet another round of pleading amendments to 
24  either set of plaintiffs.  The Emami plaintiffs have had multiple opportunities to amend, in which 
25  case the Court’s discretion to deny further amendment is especially broad.  See Chodos v. West  
26  // 
27  // 
28  // 
9 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 152   Filed 06/05/20   Page 10 of 10
 
1  Publishing Co., 292 F.3d 992, 1003 (9th Cir. 2002).  So too for the Pars plaintiffs, given the 
2  procedural context of these closely related cases.   
3  IT IS SO ORDERED. 
4  Dated:  June 5, 2020  
5

JAMES DONATO

1
NOTICE OF MOTION AND MOTION TO DISMISS 
2
  PLEASE TAKE NOTICE that on July 25, 2019, at 10:00 a.m., before the Honorable James 
3
Donato of the United States District Court for the Northern District of California, in Courtroom 
4
11 of the 19th Floor of the Philip E. Burton Courthouse and Federal Building, 450 Golden Gate 
5
Avenue, San Francisco, California, Defendants will move this Court to dismiss all claims in this 
6 case or, alternatively, for summary judgment in Defendants’ favor. 
7   Defendants’ motion is being made pursuant to Rules 12(b)(6) and 56 of the Federal Rules 
8 of Civil Procedure. The bases for this are set forth more fully in the following Memorandum of 
9 Points and Authorities.
10
11
12
13
14

iii 
 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 98   Filed 06/13/19   Page 6 of 30
 
 
1
MEMORANDUM OF POINTS AND AUTHORITIES 
2
I.  INTRODUCTION 
3
This is an unusual action—Plaintiffs bring what they plead as an APA claim to challenge 
4
the implementation of the waiver provision in Presidential Proclamation 9645, 82 Fed. Reg. 45161 
5
(Sept. 24, 2017), which the Supreme Court recently upheld in Hawaii v. Trump, 138 S. Ct. 2392 
6 (2018). But Plaintiffs identify no agency policy that they claim is invalid or improper, and they 
7 challenge individual waiver denials despite the doctrine of consular nonreviewabilty. Plaintiffs 
8 assert that the waiver process is “a sham”—essentially a process that is not being implemented at 
9 all. This Court recognized the unusual nature of this APA claim in its motion to dismiss ruling. 
10 See Dkt. No. 74. This Court explained that the only viable inquiry was into whether the State 
Department  was  in  fact  implementing  the  waiver  provision  pursuant to  guidance  issued  to 
11
implement the Proclamation. The government’s record answers this question definitively and in 
12
the affirmative: the State Department has issued detailed guidance to its consular officers and 
13
continues to update that guidance to assist them in processing waiver requests. And those officers 
14
are carrying out their duties in good faith, authorizing thousands of waivers and conducting 
15
burdensome and time-consuming national security vetting on many thousands more. The status of 
16
the individual Plaintiff cases shows this process is ongoing. Because the process is not a sham, and 
17
guidance has been issued, this Court should grant summary judgment to Defendants.  
18
This Court partially dismissed this matter in February. The Court allowed Plaintiffs’ 
19
Administrative Procedure Act (APA) challenge to proceed in a limited way, based on its finding 
20
that Plaintiffs stated a claim under United States ex rel. Accardi v. Shaughnessy, 347 U.S. 260 
21
(1954), finding that “the heart of the APA claim is that the State Department has acted arbitrarily 
22
and unlawfully by disregarding its own procedures and rules in administering the waiver program.” 
23
See Dkt. No. 74 at 13-16. The Court dismissed Plaintiffs’ constitutional claims, holding that 
24 Plaintiffs failed to allege any constitutionally protected fundamental right, Dkt. No. 74 at 16-17, 
25 and that Hawaii precludes their argument that a high proportion of waiver denials could constitute 
26 inherently  unconstitutional  discrimination.  Id.  at  17.  The  Court  also  dismissed  Plaintiffs’ 
27 mandamus claim as redundant.  
28 Plaintiffs new complaint should be dismissed for largely the same reasons. First, Plaintiffs’ 
1 
 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 98   Filed 06/13/19   Page 7 of 30
 
 
1
Accardi claim, unless very narrowly focused on whether the waiver process is being implemented 
2
at all, is too amorphous and does not specifically allege that any particular aspect of the process 
3
violates  the  Proclamation  or  State  Department  guidance.  Further,  the  Proclamation  and  its 
4
implementing guidance are neither regulations nor internal documents that create procedural 
5
rights. Second, Plaintiffs’ due process, equal protection, and mandamus claims have already been 
6 resolved by this Court and have not substantively changed in the new complaint. 
7 Should the Court deny the instant motion to dismiss, Defendants, in the alternative, move 
8 for summary judgment based on the administrative record submitted to the Court, which includes 
9 the various types of guidance provided to consular officers to assist them in resolving waiver 
10 requests, the factual material showing the progress made in each of the Plaintiffs’ individual cases, 
and statistics recently provided to Congress showing the active and ongoing implementation of the 
11
waiver provision. As this Court has noted, the “gravamen of the complaint” here is that the 
12
government has disregarded its own guidance about visa and waiver adjudications under the 
13
Proclamation “in favor of a policy of blanket denials.” See Dkt. No. 74, at 12:6-8. As this Court 
14
explained, the government’s Accardi defense “puts substantial emphasis on a number of factual 
15
matters” such as “waiver reviews and approval figures” and is “properly addressed in a summary 
16
judgment motion (if truly undisputed).” Id. at 16. As the accompanying certified administrative 
17
record and congressional reporting shows there is no such policy of blanket denials; instead, since 
18
the Proclamation went into effect, relevant agencies have issued guidance to consular officers to 
19
assist them in adjudicating visa waiver requests.  
20
Consular officers, moreover, have been processing and reviewing a vast number of visa 
21
applications on an individualized basis: over 3,000 waiver requests granted as of the end of March. 
22
An additional 12,000—over 26 percent of those considered for waivers—are undergoing security 
23
vetting,  which  is  a  rigorous,  time-consuming  process  that  is  fully  consistent  with  the 
24 Proclamation’s direction that waivers be granted only to those who pose no national security or 
25 public safety risk given fundamental flaws in the identification infrastructure or cooperativeness 
26 of the countries subject to the Proclamation, a concern the Supreme Court expressly validated. 
27 There can be no real factual dispute over these processing statistics or the existence of the guidance 
28 to consular officers. Indeed, Plaintiffs are unable to demonstrate any violation of law even as to 
2 
 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 98   Filed 06/13/19   Page 8 of 30
 
 
1
their own cases, where the record reveals that they—or their family members—have been issued 
2
visas, are still undergoing consideration for waivers, or have been refused after having been found 
3
ineligible for a waiver. 
4
In sum, Defendants are implementing the waiver provision in an ordered and deliberate 
5
way, giving due consideration not only to the demonstrated interests of individual applicants but 
6 also to the abiding concerns of national security and public safety that gave rise to the Proclamation 
7 in the first place. Simply put, there is no viable allegation that Defendants have not implemented 
8 the Proclamation’s waiver process in good faith, or that the waiver process is a “sham.” 
9 II.  BACKGROUND 
10 A.  The Proclamation’s Waiver Process   
11 At  issue  is  the  implementation  of  the  Proclamation’s  waiver  provision.  Subject  to 
exceptions not relevant here, the Proclamation suspends entry into the United States of nationals 
12
of several identified countries of concern. See 82 Fed. Reg. 45161 § 2(g). A consular officer may 
13
nonetheless, as a matter of discretion, “grant waivers on a case-by-case basis to permit the entry 
14
of foreign nationals for whom entry is otherwise suspended.” Id. § 3(c). Notably, visa applicants 
15
are not refused pursuant to the Proclamation if they are ineligible to obtain visas on other grounds 
16
or if their applications are rejected for reasons other than the Proclamation’s entry restrictions. An 
17
applicant is refused under the Proclamation only if it constitutes the sole basis for visa refusal. By 
18
extension, only an applicant refused based solely on the Proclamation may be considered for a 
19
waiver under it. See id. § 3(a), (c). 
20
  As the State Department’s publicly accessible guidance explains, there is no separate 
21
application for a waiver: “An individual who seeks to travel to the United States should apply for 
22
a visa and disclose during the visa interview any information that might demonstrate that he or she 
23
is eligible for a waiver.” U.S. Department of State – Bureau of Consular Affairs, June 26 Supreme 
24
Court  Decision  on  Presidential  Proclamation  9645  (“State  Dep’t  Website”),  available  at 
25 https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/us-visas/visa-information-resources/presidential-
26 proclamation-archive/june_26_supreme_court_decision_on_presidential_proclamation9645.html 
27 (last visited June 11, 2019); A.R. 296, 299, 306, 309, 317, 319. This is consistent with other visa-
28 application  procedures,  such  as  nonimmigrant  visa  waivers,  which  do  not  have  a  separate 
3 
 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 98   Filed 06/13/19   Page 9 of 30
 
 
1
application.  See  Foreign  Affairs  Manual  (“FAM”)  305.4-3,  available  at 
2
https://fam.state.gov/fam/09FAM/09FAM030504.html.  The  Proclamation  sets  out  a  non-
3
exhaustive list of examples elucidating when a waiver “may be appropriate,” while emphasizing 
4
that “[c]ase-by-case waivers may not be granted categorically.” 82 Fed. Reg. at 45168-69, 
5
§ 3(c)(iv).  The  Proclamation  mandates  that  “[t]he  Secretary  of  State  and  the  Secretary  of 
6 Homeland Security shall coordinate to adopt guidance addressing the circumstances in which 
7 waivers may be appropriate.” Id. at 45168, § 3(c). Such guidance is not required to be made public, 
8 and the State Department often provides internal guidance to consular officers to avoid the risk 
9 that visa applicants will misuse it. A.R. 288, 297, 308, 318. 
10 Since the promulgation of the Proclamation, the State Department has provided answers 
11 on its public website to a number of common questions regarding the mechanics of the waiver 
12 process. See State Dep’t Website. It has also released hundreds of pages of guidance, both general 
13 and in specific cases. See, e.g., A.R. 13-155; U.S. Department of State, Virtual Reading Room 
14 Documents Search Results.2 This Court has previously noted that such online postings constitute 
15 the State Department’s outward-facing guidance on the waiver process. Dkt. No. 74, at 14:18-19. 
16 The  internal  waiver  guidance  that  has  been  promulgated,  and  submitted  in  the 
17 administrative record for this Court’s review, consists of several types of material. First, updates 
18 to the Foreign Affairs Manual have provided visa adjudication guidance to consular officers by 
19 the State Department. A.R. 3-11. Second, detailed operational Q&As have addressed specific 
20 issues that might arise in applying the Proclamation and its waiver provisions, and are updated on 
21 a rolling basis. A.R. 13-155. Third, cables have regularly been issued to consular posts, as the State 
22 Department  has  endeavored  to  ensure  that  its  personnel  are  in  full  compliance  with  the 
23 Proclamation. A.R. 157-98. Fourth, various training materials have been produced for the benefit 
24 of consular officers, including presentations, flowcharts, and reference guides. A.R. 200-84, 
25 327-45. Fifth, press guidance has laid out waiver-related issues suitable for explanation to the 
26 public. A.R. 286-325. 
                                                 
27
2  Available  at    https://foia.state.gov/Search/results.aspx?searchText=Presidential+Proclamation+9645&beginDate 
28
=20170901 &endDate=20190612&publishedBeginDate=&publishedEndDate=&caseNumber=. 
4 
 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 98   Filed 06/13/19   Page 10 of 30
 
 
1
A waiver may be granted only if an applicant shows the following: (1) denying entry would 
2
cause undue hardship, (2) entry would be in the national interest of the United States, and (3) entry 
3
would not pose a threat to the national security or public safety of the United States. 82 Fed. Reg. 
4
at 45168, § 3(c). As of March 31, 2019, 3,071 visa applicants have been given waivers and issued 
5
visas. See Dep’t of State Report to Congress: Implementation of Presidential Proclamation 9645 – 
6 December 8, 2017, to March 31, 2019 (“State Dep’t Report”).3 While the first two prongs of waiver 
7 eligibility may be readily resolved based on the materials submitted by the applicant, an analysis 
8 of the third prong can prove time-consuming because the applicant must be carefully vetted in 
9 light of the identity sharing problems identified as the basis for the Proclamation. As of March 31,

the first two conditions for a waiver and are now under review to determine whether they meet the

national security and public safety criterion. See id.

III.  STANDARD OF REVIEW 
13
The APA provides for judicial review of final agency action. See 5 U.S.C. §§ 702, 704. It 
14
authorizes courts to “hold unlawful and set aside” only those agency actions, findings, and 
15
conclusions it finds to be “arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, or otherwise not in 
16
accordance with the law.” 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(A). The administrative record is the exclusive basis 
17
for the Court’s review. See id. at 743-44 (1985) (“The task of the reviewing court is to apply the 
18
appropriate APA standard of review, 5 U.S.C. § 706, to the agency decision based on the record 
19
the agency presents to the reviewing court.”); Camp v. Pitts, 411 U.S. 138, 142 (1973) (per curiam) 
20
(“the focal point for judicial review should be the administrative record in existence, not some new 
21
record made initially in the reviewing court”). 
22
Summary judgment under Rule 56 is appropriate to resolve APA challenges. See Nw. 
23
Motorcycle Ass’n v. U.S. Dep’t Agric., 18 F.3d 1468, 1471–72 (9th Cir. 1994). Even if the parties 
24
dispute the facts before the administrative agency, “the function of the district court is to determine 
25
whether or not as a matter of law the evidence in the administrative record permitted the agency 
26
to make the decision it did.” Occidental Engineering Co. v. Immigration & Naturalization Service, 
27
753 F.2d 766, 769 (9th Cir. 1985); see also City & Cnty. of San Francisco v. United States, 130 
28

F.3d 873, 877 (9th Cir. 1997).

4 1.  Plaintiffs’ fail to state a claim under the Accardi doctrine. 
5 In its February 4, 2019 Order, the Court found that Plaintiffs stated a claim under Accardi, 
6 347 U.S. 260, and “the heart of the APA claim is that the State Department has acted arbitrarily 
7 and unlawfully by disregarding its own procedures and rules in administering the waiver program.” 
See Dkt. No. 74 at 13-16. This Court, however, did not have the benefit of detailed briefing from 
8
the Government on Accardi. That claim should now be dismissed because such a claim is too 
9

10

11

12
As an initial matter, even if Accardi’s directive that an agency must follow its own 
13
regulations may make sense when analyzing a specific agency action, it makes little sense when 
14
there is no final agency action subject to review, which is the case here given consular non-
15
reviewability. Accardi—even where it applies—is not a license to engage in roving oversight of 
16
an agency’s implementation of a regulatory scheme, and there are no cases where it has been 
17
applied in the manner Plaintiffs seek to apply it here. See Order at 18 (recognizing a request to 
18
“order defendants to fulfill their duties under the Proclamation” may be “impermissible”).  
19
Further, Accardi is inapplicable here because the Proclamation is not a regulation. Accardi, 
20
347 U.S. at 268. It is neither the nature nor the purpose of the Proclamation waiver provisions to 
21 confer a legally enforceable benefit or right in any person, as the Proclamation itself expressly 
22 acknowledges. Proclamation, § 9(c). Moreover, the implementing guidance, including the Foreign 
23 Affairs Manual, simply furnishes additional details regarding the waiver process, which ultimately 
24 consists of discretionary determinations made by consular officers as expressly provided by the 
25 Proclamation. A.R. 3-11. The Ninth Circuit has held that the Accardi doctrine is inapplicable in 
the context most similar to this one—with respect to internal operating guidelines that preserve the 
26
exercise of agency discretion as in this case. See Mada-Luna v. Fitzpatrick, 813 F.2d 1006, 1009 
27
(9th Cir. 1987) (Operating instructions are “general statements of policy” because the instructions 
28

persevered the agency’s flexibility and opportunity to make discretionary determinations.). As the

1.  The administrative record emphatically demonstrates that the waiver process 
14 is not a sham. 
15 Contrary to Plaintiffs’ depiction of the waiver process as “arbitrary and ad hoc,” SAC ¶ 94, 
16 the administrative record shows that Defendants have applied the waiver provision in an orderly 
17 way, taking deliberate measures to adhere to the Proclamation and any related guidance. The 
18 waiver process is operating properly and is not a sham. This is established by the administrative 
19 record, which shows that (1) the State Department has regularly issued detailed internal guidance 
20 to inform consular officers’ application of the Proclamation’s waiver criteria, (2) each applicant 
21 who meets the first two prongs for a waiver is properly vetted for national security or public safety 
22 concerns,  (3) consular  officers  are  afforded  discretion  to  make  case-by-case  waiver 
23 determinations, which are not reviewable and are in any event entitled to a presumption of 
24 regularity, (4) the application process is legitimate, as applicants are automatically considered for 
25 waivers as part of a unitary visa application process consistent with other types of waiver requests, 
26 and (5) numerous applicants, including most Plaintiffs, either have been found eligible for waivers 
27 and issued visas or continue to receive administrative processing after the consular officer made a 
28 preliminary  finding  regarding  the  undue  hardship  and  national  interest  criteria.  The  record

confirms, moreover, that the Accardi doctrine does not apply in this case, as consular officers do

b.  National security vetting 
15
The most time-consuming part of the waiver process is the security vetting, whereby every 
16
applicant must undergo thorough vetting to ensure they do not present a national security or public 
17
safety risk. That vetting—which is similar to many other vetting processes in the visa adjudication 
18
system where consular officers consult law enforcement partners to help evaluate applicants—is 
19
critical to achieve a fundamental purpose of the Proclamation given the identity management and 
20
cooperation problems with the subject countries. 82 Fed. Reg. at 45168, § 3(c)(i)(B) (waiver may 
21
be granted only if the applicant demonstrates to the consular officer’s satisfaction that “entry would 
22
not pose a threat to the national security or public safety of the United States”). Vetting aliens to 
23
ensure that there is no threat to national security or public safety is not a sham, and Plaintiffs’ 
24
complaint raises no colorable allegation that the national security vetting is illegitimate or 
25
improper in any way. Thus, the part of the waiver process that causes the most delay is not in any 
26
way being challenged in the operative complaint. 
27
The Proclamation, from the outset, explains that the purpose of its entry restrictions is to

3
(such “protocols and practices of foreign governments are important for the effectiveness of the 
4
screening and vetting protocols and procedures of the United States,” which in turn “play a critical 
5
role” in protecting U.S. “citizens from terrorist attacks and other public-safety threats”); A.R. 3.

The restrictions are intended to “encourage the countries to work with the United States to address

those inadequacies and risks so that the restrictions and limitations . . . may be relaxed or removed

as soon as possible,” 82 Fed. Reg. at 45164, § 1(h), as happened with Chad. A.R. 185-87, 320. 
9
Short of that, however, the Proclamation contemplates that the restrictions must stay in place, “both 
10
to protect national security and public safety, and to induce improvements by [the identified] 
11
countries.” See Hawaii, 138 S. Ct. at 2409. The Supreme Court expressly upheld the Proclamation 
12
based on this rationale. Id. at 2410. 
13
A substantial portion of the guidance to consular officers concerns this security vetting—
14
and most of that is classified or law enforcement sensitive because, if disclosed, just as with 
15
security vetting in other visa contexts, it would create the highest risk of providing a roadmap for 
16
malign actors intent on defrauding the government to skirt the national security and public safety 
17
checks. See, e.g., A.R. 9-10 (9 F.A.M. 302.14-10(E)(2) (redacted material detailing steps for 
18
consular officer to take in conducting security vetting)); A.R. 39, 41-42, 50, 70-71, 79-80, 159-62 
19
(same); A.R. 183 (referencing classified guidance); see also Dkt. No. ¶ 77 n.7 (discussing 
20
analogous administrative processing procedures). The primary public-facing cable addressing this 
21
vetting is 17 STATE 56801, with unclassified excerpts appearing at A.R. 157-162. This cable 
22
shows that a substantial manual investigation by the consular officer is needed in each case, who 
23
considers an exceedingly broad swath of information from interagency partners before rendering 
24
a judgment as to whether the applicant poses a security threat. See A.R. 157. In doing this, 
25
“consular  officers  must  understand  the  specific  circumstances  that  led  to  each  [identified] 
26
country’s designation as inadequate,” including information relating to the likelihood a passport 
27
could be fraudulent, and whether the country shares information regarding identity, criminal 
28
16 
 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 98   Filed 06/13/19   Page 22 of 30
 
 
1
history, or suspected terrorists. A.R. 157-58. Given these concerns about identity management that 
2
gave rise to the Proclamation, this requires “a case by case determination to verify that an 
3
applicant’s identity as recorded in a passport is bona fide and that there is no indication that he or 
4
she has engaged in terrorist or criminal activities.” A.R. 157. This individual investigation is 
5
“resource intensive for posts and interagency partners.” Id. The guidance makes it clear that 
6
consular officials are to provide case notes assessing this factor based on their investigation and 
7
consultation with partners and foreign governments. A.R. 79-80, 169. While this process is 
8
“resource intensive,” it is not a “sham,” and it is one that ultimately results in a judgment made by 
9
the consular officer. A.R. 157. 
10
Given that the entry restrictions were introduced specifically to redress the “significant 
11
gaps” in the identity-management and information-sharing practices of several countries, see 82 
12
Fed. Reg. at 45164, § 1(h)(ii), it would run counter to the very purpose and design of the 
13
Proclamation not to consider those gaps when adjudicating visa applications from affected foreign 
14
nationals. Further, while the first two prongs can be assessed relatively quickly on the materials 
15
and statements submitted by the applicant, the third component of the waiver analysis may take 
16
considerably  more  time—challenging  consular  officers  not  only  to  probe  the  applicant’s 
17
background for fraud, criminal, or terrorist concerns, but also to scrutinize the gathered evidence 
18
in  light  of  the  conditions  that  led  the  applicant’s  country  to  be  “deemed  ‘inadequate’  on 
19
information sharing” in the first place. See A.R. 157. The patient and thorough approach adopted 
20
by  consular  officers  to  investigate  applicants  for  security  concerns  reflects  the  good  faith 
21
implementation of a Proclamation designed to eliminate national security risks in cases where 
22
information sharing or cooperation is inadequate, and that extensive effort is not what one would 
23
expect if the process were in fact a “sham.”  
24
c.  Consular officers’ function in adjudicating waivers 
25
The central role afforded to consular officers, and the presumption of regularity that their 
26
decisions enjoy, also shows that the waiver process is not a sham. Throughout the record, there is 
27
a clear recognition that consular officers are authorized to make, and in fact are the ones actually 
28
17 
 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 98   Filed 06/13/19   Page 23 of 30
 
 
1
making,  waiver  decisions  with  respect  to  visa  applicants  on  a  case-by-case  basis.  The 
2
Proclamation’s direction that consular officers have discretion to adjudicate waivers is reiterated 
3
throughout various internal guidance—perhaps most prominently in the Foreign Affairs Manual 
4
(“FAM”), which punctuates that no waiver can be granted until the consular officer is satisfied that 
5
the applicant has met all three waiver conditions.4 See A.R. 7-11. More than once, the FAM makes 
6
sure to directly address consular officers while setting out waiver-related guidance, leaving no 
7
uncertainty as to who is responsible for assessing waiver eligibility and adjudicating visas in 
8
individual cases. See, e.g., A.R. 7 (“You must determine whether the applicant may qualify for a 
9
waiver” (emphasis added)); A.R. 9 (“If the applicant qualifies for a waiver, you may issue the 
10
visa.” (emphasis added)). 
11
Similarly, the Q&As make plain that “Consular officers may grant waivers on a case-by-
12
case basis when the applicant demonstrates to the officer’s satisfaction that the [waiver] criteria 
13
apply.” A.R. 19 (emphasis added). Some of the Q&As provide for consultation with supervisors 
14
such as the visa chief or the consular section chief at the consular post, see A.R. 131—but those 
15
supervisory personnel are generally also consular officers at the post who themselves adjudicate 
16
visas and waivers.5 A.R. 19, 39, 68, 99, 131. And while consular officers may find themselves 
17
consulting with interagency partners at certain points in the process—especially during the process 
18
of national security vetting, where information from interagency partners is critical—they do not 
19
relinquish any of their discretion in applying the waiver criteria to the applicant’s case, including 
20
in relation to the third prong. A.R. 157-59. As the guidance makes clear, an applicant must 
21
“demonstrate[] to the [consular] officer’s satisfaction” that her entry would pose no threat to 
22
national security or public safety before a waiver can be granted. A.R. 19, 38, 67, 130-31. 
23
  Plaintiffs rely heavily on the uncorroborated statements of a former State Department 
24
                                                 
25
4 The FAM constitutes a “single, comprehensive, and authoritative source” for the State Department’s governing 
26 policies and “convey[s] codified information” for agency personnel to “carry out their responsibilities in accordance 
with statutory, executive and Department mandates.” See U.S. Department of State, Foreign Affairs Manual and 
27 Handbook, available at https://fam.state.gov/. 
5 According to the Q&As, “[s]ole consular officers do not need concurrence from their supervisor for waivers or 
28
exceptions, but should seek [visa office] concurrence on their decisions to grant waivers.” A.R. 23, 50, 80, 111, 143. 
18 
 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 98   Filed 06/13/19   Page 24 of 30
 
 
1
employee, Christopher Richardson, who alleged many months ago, in a different case, without 
2
being subject to adversarial, that consular officers are shut out from the decision-making process 
3
to grant or deny waivers. See generally SAC ¶¶ 3, 67, 72, 75, 90-93. According to Richardson, “it 
4
is understood that there really is no waiver [process]” and consular officers are forced “to 
5
determine at all possible cost” that all applicants are ineligible “to even apply for a waiver.” See, 
6
e.g., Dkt. No. 77-3; SAC ¶ 91. But Richardson’s qualifications to opine on the waiver process are 
7
dubious at best. Before he retired from the Department in March of 2018—just a few months after 
8
the Proclamation went into effect—he served as the American Citizens Services Chief at the U.S. 
9
Embassy in Madrid. Id. ¶ 155. Spain is not one of the countries of concern identified in the 
10
Proclamation, nor do American citizens apply for visas as they must travel with passports. See 
11
8 U.S.C. § 1185(b) (providing that “it shall be unlawful for any citizen of the United States to 
12
depart from or enter, or attempt to depart from or enter, the United States unless he bears a valid 
13
United states passport”). Richardson also does not claim that he adjudicated visa applications, 
14
applied the Proclamation, or ever played any part in carrying out the Proclamation’s waiver 
15
provision, and his credentials suggest that he did not. In short, other than Richardson’s vague 
16
conjecture that the waiver process somehow is a sham, Plaintiffs point to nothing that would allow 
17
this Court to reasonably conclude that consular officers—despite all the record evidence to the 
18
contrary—have been directed to deny all waiver applications and disregard the hundreds of pages 
19
of guidance that are included in the administrative record.6 Richardson’s declaration was before 
20
the court in Alharbi v. Miller, No. 17-cv-2435-BMC (E.D.N.Y. Apr. 25, 2018), Dkt. No. 42-2, but 
21
the court dismissed that case after finding that the plaintiffs there had made no plausible or 
22
particular allegations of bad faith by agency actors. Id., Dkt. No. 82, at 26. 
23
Thus, while consular officers may at times have to confer with supervisors or agency 
24
partners, especially with respect to the resource-intensive national security assessment, that 
25
collaborative element does not alter the fact that the consular officer oversees all steps of the waiver 
26
                                                 
27
6 Plaintiffs refer to statements from other former consular officers as evidence of a fraudulent waiver process. See, 
28
e.g., SAC ¶ 89. But because Plaintiffs never identify these individuals, their alleged statements should hold no weight.  
19 
 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 98   Filed 06/13/19   Page 25 of 30
 
 
1
adjudication  and  ultimately  decides  in  her  discretion  to  grant  or  deny  a  waiver  under  the 
2
Proclamation. A.R. 157. 
3
d.  Application process 
4
The application process further confirms that implementation of the waiver provision is 
5
not a sham by ensuring that all individuals subject to the Proclamation receive full consideration 
6
for a waiver as a matter of course. While the waiver provision places the burden on the applicant 
7
to demonstrate to the satisfaction of the consular officer that a waiver is warranted, “[t]here is no 
8
separate application for a waiver. An individual who seeks to travel to the United States should 
9
apply for a visa and disclose during the visa interview any information that might demonstrate that 
10
he or she is eligible for a waiver.” State Dep’t Website. This unitary process, whereby applicants 
11
refused visas under the Proclamation are still considered for a waiver with an opportunity to 
12
provide relevant information but without any further action on their end, is consistent with the 
13
terms of the Proclamation, which does not dictate any particular method by which consular officers 
14
must consider waiver eligibility, but mandates only that waiver eligibility be considered. See 82 
15
Fed. Reg. at 45168, § 3(c). Indeed, requiring applicants to file a separate application for a waiver, 
16
with largely duplicative evidence, would burden both the applicant and the consular officer, who 
17
in any case would have to interview the applicant on his larger request for a visa. An automatic 
18
process, on the other hand, streamlines application processing and prevents applicants from being 
19
penalized for being unfamiliar with the general framework of the Proclamation and the ways in 
20
which its various parts intersect. 
21
As to the argument that a separate waiver form, however onerous, could enable applicants 
22
to provide more evidence in support of their claim than through a unitary visa application, the State 
23
Department has made sure to give public notice that applicants, during the visa interview, should 
24
disclose “any information that might demonstrate that he or she is eligible for a waiver.” State 
25
Dep’t Website. Further, as amply shown above, consular officers are reminded regularly that the 
26
Proclamation itself mandates that refused visa applicants be considered for waivers, and there is 
27
no evidence that they have ever attempted to disobey that express directive. The first two waiver 
28
20 
 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 98   Filed 06/13/19   Page 26 of 30
 
 
1
prongs,  in  any  case,  can  be  evaluated  through  relatively  straightforward  inquiries  of  the 
2
applicant—and the visa applicant is provided the information needed to substantiate a claim of 
3
severe hardship or other compelling reason for wanting to travel to the United States.7 And should 
4
the applicant still, for some reason, believe that she had been deprived of a full opportunity to 
5
establish her case for a visa, the regulations allow her to present further evidence regarding her 
6
eligibility to the consular officer who adjudicated his case for up to one year from the date of her 
7
refusal. See 22 C.F.R. § 42.81(e). 
8
Some of the named Plaintiffs allege that they submitted visa applications and were 
9
interviewed on those applications before the Proclamation went into effect and thus were never 
10
properly considered for waivers. Dkt. No. 81, ¶¶ 22, 77, 196, 251, 260, 278, 314. That allegation 
11
is unfounded and, in any case, confuted by the record. As their individual declarations show, those 
12
Plaintiffs had their applications readjudicated after the Proclamation took effect. They were 
13
refused visas under 8 U.S.C. § 1182(f) pursuant to the Proclamation and automatically considered 
14
for waivers. A.R. 347 60, ¶¶ 5, 6, 7, 9, 11-13, 20, 22 24, 26, 28. Some of those Plaintiffs were 
15
denied waivers after failing to meet the mandatory criteria, while others are still undergoing 
16
consideration for a waiver of the Proclamation’s entry restrictions. If anything, the orderly way in 
17
which  all  Plaintiffs’  cases  have  been  handled—irrespective  of  when  they  arose—plainly 
18
demonstrates that Defendants are implementing the waiver process. 
19
e.  Waiver-related statistics 
20
Statistics relating to the implementation of the Proclamation unmistakably demonstrate that 
21
the waiver process is not a sham. According to data recently released in the quarterly State 
22
Department report on the waiver process, consular officers, between December 8, 2017, and March 
23                                                  
7 Because the first two waiver prongs demand an inquiry into individual facts and can best be assessed by the consular 
24
officer, who is directly presented with the applicant’s evidence, it is unsurprising that much of the State Department’s 
publicly available guidance pertain to undue hardship and national interest. See A.R. 19, 38, 67, 98, 131 (each 
25
explaining that “[t]he requirement for issuance to be in the national interest may be met if a U.S. person or entity 
would suffer hardship if the applicant could not travel until after visa restrictions imposed with respect to nationals of 
26
that country are lifted” (emphasis in original)). Those prongs intersect where “[t]he required level of hardship to an 
applicant may vary with the level of U.S. national interest in facilitating the applicant’s travel to the United States.” 
27
A.R. 140. Thus, “[w]hen assessing national interest, consular officers should consider hardship suffered by a U.S. 
person or entity . . . . If an applicant’s travel is related to a program or policy objective of the U.S. government, then 
28
the national interest can be considered higher, and the hardship to the applicant would not need to be as severe.” Id. 
21 
 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 98   Filed 06/13/19   Page 27 of 30
 
 
1
31, 2019, received 178,681 visa applications from nationals of the affected countries. State Dep’t 
2
Report, at 7-16. Of those, only 60,275 applications—or about a third of all applications—were 
3
affected by the Proclamation. Id. And of those 60,275 affected applicants, 10,734 were refused 
4
visas for reasons unrelated to the Proclamation, whereas 6,893 were issued visas under the 
5
Proclamation, including 3,071 applicants as a result of a waiver. Id. at 16-20, 26-36. Those 3,071 
6
individuals were granted waivers after having been found to meet all three waiver criteria—a figure 
7
that represents approximately 6.7 percent of all applications considered for a waiver under the 
8
Proclamation. Id. at 3. Notably, more than 12,000 applicants—or over 26 percent of those 
9
considered for waivers—have been found to meet the first two waiver prongs and are currently 
10
undergoing a manual “interagency security review to resolve whether their entry would not pose 
11
a threat to the national security or public safety.” Id. As we have explained, it is that vetting that 
12
is most time-consuming and that has led to frustration by applicants. Thus, contrary to Plaintiffs’ 
13
suggestion of a blanket waiver denial policy, the evidence demonstrates that there are applicants 
14
currently occupying every stage of the multi-step waiver process, and proceeding through that 
15
process in a structured way.  
16
Plaintiffs also refer to some statistical data—from early 2018, just a few months after the 
17
Proclamation went into effect—to allege that Defendants have adopted a blanket denial policy. 
18
Dkt. No. 1 ¶¶ 136-54. Plaintiffs, in fact, rest much of their case on those expired statistics, arguing 
19
that because “only an exceedingly small number of visa applicants are actually granted waivers,” 
20
the figures “confirm that [the waiver process] is, indeed, window dressing.” Id. ¶ 138. Although 
21
the referenced data in fact reveals that, even in the Proclamation’s incipiency, applicants were 
22
being processed and cleared for waivers, Plaintiffs insinuate that the number of waiver grants 
23
during  that  period  was  either  too  low  or  contrived.  Id.  ¶¶ 139-41,  145  (claiming  that  the 
24
government “appeared to start granting waivers at a relatively faster rate” in light of developments 
25
in Hawaii), 148-50. In doing so, however, Plaintiffs divorce the waiver statistics from the only 
26
context in which those numbers can be properly viewed. Statistics from the very beginning of the 
27
waiver process, just as the program was being developed and implemented after the Supreme Court 
28
22 
 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 98   Filed 06/13/19   Page 28 of 30
 
 
1
granted  a  stay  that  permitted  the  Proclamation  to  take  effect  in  December  2017,  are  not 
2
representative and should be given little weight by this Court. Indeed, the numerical cherry-picking 
3
in which Plaintiffs engage—suggesting, for example, that the waiver process is irregular simply 
4
because “less than 2% of visa applicants . . . had been granted waivers as of April 30, 2018”— is 
5
based on information that the Supreme Court had before it and represents the kind of statistical 
6
manipulation that the Supreme Court expressly disfavored in Hawaii. See id. at 2423 n.7. If 
7
Plaintiffs had their way, this Court would be put in the untenable position of determining whether 
8
the number of waiver grants, which naturally changes over time, is somehow too low—an 
9
impossible task that the Court should decline to take on. 
10
In citing waiver statistics to challenge the waiver process, Plaintiffs also misapprehend the 
11
basic framework in which waiver adjudications take place. As discussed above, no waiver can be 
12
granted until a consular officer has made an individualized determination that the applicant has 
13
met the three criteria set out in the Proclamation—to wit, undue burden, national interest, and 
14
national security/public safety. See 82 Fed. Reg. at 45168, § 3(c). It is a wide and exhaustive 
15
undertaking—so much so that the refusal letters provided to visa applicants who remain eligible 
16
for waivers forewarn that the waiver assessment “can be a lengthy process.” A.R. 10, 11, 152, 340, 
17
341; see Singh v. Still, 470 F. Supp. 2d 1064, 1068 (N.D. Cal. 2007) (holding that in determining 
18
whether an agency has unreasonably delayed in processing an immigration application, courts 
19
typically look to “the source of the delay—e.g., the complexity of the investigation as well as the 
20
extent  to  which  the  defendant  participated  in  delaying  the  proceeding”).  Even  before  the 
21
Proclamation’s promulgation, case-by-case adjudications of visa petitions frequently took months, 
22
in part, because of required background checks. See I.N.S. v. Miranda, 459 U.S. 14, 15, 18 (1982) 
23
(finding that INS’s failure to act on immigrant visa petition for eighteen months did not constitute 
24
unreasonable delay because of “the number of the applications received by the INS and the need 
25
to  investigate  their  validity”);  Sayyadinejead  v.  Chertoff,  No.  07-cv-0631-JAH,  2007  WL 
26
4410356, at *6 (S.D. Cal. Dec. 14, 2007) (finding that, despite a delay of three years on account 
27
of FBI background checks, USCIS and the FBI were “taking reasonable precautions as public 
28
23 
 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 98   Filed 06/13/19   Page 29 of 30
 
 
1
safety require[d] them to do, and [were] also doing everything possible to ensure that the [p]laintiff 
2
wait[ed] no longer than necessary to receive permanent status”). Thus, while Plaintiffs complain 
3
about what they deem to be excessively low numbers of waiver grants, they fail to consider that 
4
those statistics are entwined with the time it takes to thoroughly complete each individual waiver 
5
adjudication. And it is not unreasonable that the waiver statistics, thus far, have not been any 
6
higher, where consular officers must adjudicate a daunting volume of waiver applications and 
7
endeavor “to mitigate the risks” to national security and public safety that might attend any one of 
8
those determinations. A.R. 169, 180. 
9
Plaintiffs, in short, proffer only “selective statistics” and “anecdotal evidence” to protest 
10
that “not enough individuals are receiving waivers.” See Hawaii, 138 S. Ct. at 2423 n.7. Their 
11
complaint, at bottom, is rooted simply in their dissatisfaction with the rate at which consular 
12
officers have adjudicated waiver applications and the number of waivers that those officers have 
13
granted. Courts have declined to step in in individual cases where adjudications of similar requests 
14
have taken years—this Court should likewise decline to oversee a challenging and multi-faceted 
15
waiver process where many cases are delayed due to essential national security vetting. Plaintiffs’ 
16
claims relating to delay are far too meager to go forward, especially where they have not proffered 
17
any evidence or viable claim that the government has failed to comply with its own waiver 
18
guidance and procedures. 
19
*** 
20
  Incidentally, the sound implementation of the waiver provision can also be seen in the case 
21
histories of Plaintiffs themselves. Notably, one Plaintiff has been granted an immigrant visa based 
22
on her qualification for a waiver. A.R. at 347-59 ¶ 12. Of the 26 plaintiffs for whom the State 
23
Department compiled information regarding their visa applications, consular officers determined 
24
that 12 of them met the first two waiver prongs of hardship and national interest. Id. ¶¶ 4, 7, 8, 9, 
25 10, 11, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 22. Although further vetting with respect to the third prong remains for 
26 these Plaintiffs, should the consular officers adjudicating their applications find that they would 
27 not pose a threat to national security or public safety, they would likely be granted waivers, absent 
28 any other eligibility concerns. Aside from one plaintiff who was refused a visa for a reason 
24 
 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 98   Filed 06/13/19   Page 30 of 30
 
 
1
unrelated to the Proclamation, id. ¶ 21, the remaining Plaintiffs were denied waivers after having 
2
failed to meet one or both of the first two waiver prongs, id. ¶¶ 5, 6, 18, 19, 20, 23, 24, 25, 26, 27, 
3
28,  29.  The  different  positions  that  Plaintiffs—and  all  other  applicants  covered  by  the 
4
Proclamation—currently occupy in relation to their visa proceedings illustrate that the waiver 
5
process, far from being aimless or stagnant, has been moving deliberately apace, through the 
6 combined efforts of the agencies. 
7   In short, the administrative record and publicly available information showing thousands 
8 of granted waivers decisively refute Plaintiffs’ allegations that the State Department has not 
9 followed its own guidance, or has instituted a “sham” waiver process. Defendants are entitled to 
10 summary judgment on the Accardi claim—the only claim that this Court permitted to go forward 
11 in its prior order. 
12 V.  CONCLUSION 
13    For the foregoing reasons, the Court should dismiss Plaintiffs’ SAC with prejudice or grant 
14 summary judgment to Defendants. 
15 Dated: June 13, 2019     JOSEPH H. HUNT 
Assistant Attorney General 
16           United States Department of Justice, Civil Division 
           
17           AUGUST E. FLENTJE 
          Special Counsel 
18
 
WILLIAM C. PEACHEY

          Director, Office of Immigration Litigation

20
             
By: GISELA A. WESTWATER

          Assistant Director, Office of Immigration Litigation

          Senior Litigation Counsel, Office of Immigration Litigation

03/23/20 176   ORDER. Presidential Proclamation 10141, "Ending Discriminatory 
21  Bans on Entry to the United States," 86 Fed. Reg. 7005 (2021), 
revokes Presidential Proclamation 9645 and requires, among other 
things, plans within 45 days to ensure (i) that individuals whose 
immigrant visa applications were denied under PP 9645 "may have 
their applications reconsidered," and (ii) "that visa applicants are not 
prejudiced as a result of a previous visa denial" due to PP 9645. 
Plaintiffs in these related cases acknowledge that the new 
Proclamation's requirements, if carried out by the government, may 
remedy the harms plaintiffs have alleged in these cases. See 
Emami Dkt. Nos. 173, 175. The Court consequently finds it 
appropriate to stay these cases, terminate the pending discovery 
disputes, and administratively close the cases, pending further 
developments. The parties are directed to file a joint status update 
by June 7, 2021. Signed by Judge James Donato on 3/23/2021. (This is

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 75   Filed 02/23/19   Page 1 of 68
  
1  SIRINE SHEBAYA (pro hac vice)   SHABNAM LOTFI (pro hac vice)     
NIMRA AZMI (pro hac vice)*  VERONICA SUSTIC (pro hac vice)

 Attorneys for Plaintiffs

UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
10  FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
SAN FRANCISCO DIVISION 
11 
 
 
12 
  Civil Case No. 3:18-cv-01587  
Tannaz Toloubeydokhti; Fathollah Tolou Beydokhti;   
13 
Behnaz Malekghaeini; Afrooz Kharazmi; Afshan  SECOND AMENDED CLASS 
Alamshah Zadeh; Najib Adi; Ismail Alghazali; Malik  ACTION COMPLAINT FOR 
14 
Almathil; Khalil Ali Nagi; Hezam Alarqaban;  INJUNCTIVE AND  
15  Abdurraouf Gseaa; Sudi Wardere; Khadija Aden;  DECLARATORY RELIEF AND 
Soheil Vazehrad; Atefehossadat Motavaliabyazani;  FOR WRIT OF MANDAMUS 
16  Bamshad Azizi; Roghayeh Azizikoutenaei;   
Hojjatollah Azizikoutenaei; Clyde Jean Tedrick II;    
17  Mitra Farnoodian-Tedrick; Farajollah Farnoudian; 
Farangis Emami; Maral Charkhtab Tabrizi; Zahra 
18 
Rouzbehani; Bahram Charkhtab Tabrizi; Maryam 
Mozafari; Mohammad Mehdi Mozaffary; Behnam
