Afshar Arjmand; Ehsan Heidaryan; Najmeh 
20 
Maharlouei; Nastaran Hajiheydari; Mohamad 
Hamami, 
21 
 
Plaintiffs, 
22 
 
23  -against- 
 
24  KIRSTJEN NIELSEN, in her official capacity as 
Secretary of Homeland Security; U.S. 
25 
SECOND AMENDED COMPLAINT - 1 
26 
27 
28 
 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 75   Filed 02/23/19   Page 2 of 68
  
1     
DEPARTMENT OF HOMELAND SECURITY;  
2 
MICHAEL R. POMPEO, in his official capacity as  
Secretary of State; U.S. DEPARTMENT OF 
3 
STATE; KEVIN K. MCALEENAN, in his official 
capacity as Commissioner of U.S. Customs and 
4 
Border Protection; U.S. CUSTOMS AND BORDER 
PROTECTION; L. FRANCIS CISSNA, in his 
5 
official capacity as Director of U.S. Citizenship and 
6  Immigration Services; U.S. CITIZENSHIP AND 
IMMIGRATION SERVICES,  
7   
Defendants. 
8   
 
9 
INTRODUCTION 
10 
1.  Presidential  Proclamation  9645  issued  on  September  24,  2017  (“the  Proclamation”) 
11 
prohibits the entry of all immigrants and certain categories of non-immigrants for nationals of Iran, 
12 
Libya, Somalia, Syria, and Yemen.1 The Proclamation provides for case-by-case waivers from the 
13 
ban for individuals who can “demonstrate” that denial of entry “would cause undue hardship, . . . 
14 
would not pose a threat to national security, . . . and would be in the national interest.” Ex. A, 
15 
Presidential Proclamation No. 9645, 82 Fed. Reg. 45161 (Sept. 27, 2017), § 3(c). The Proclamation 
16 
provides several examples of circumstances in which waivers may be appropriate, and further 
17 
requires  the Secretary  of  State  and  the Secretary  of  Homeland  Security  to  adopt  guidance 
18 
establishing when waivers may be appropriate for foreign nationals who would otherwise be 
19 
banned.  
20 
21  2.  To date, however, no meaningful guidance has been issued or publicly promulgated. The 
22  agencies do not appear to have established—and certainly have not provided information to the 
23 
                                                
 
24 
1 Under the terms of the Proclamation, all Syrian nationals are banned; all Libyan and Yemeni nationals seeking 
immigrant or non-immigrant B1/B2 visas are banned; all Iranian nationals except non-immigrants seeking F, M, or J 
25 
visas are banned; and all Somali nationals seeking immigrant visas are banned.  
SECOND AMENDED COMPLAINT - 2 
26 
27 
28 
 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 75   Filed 02/23/19   Page 3 of 68
  
1  public about—waiver application procedures that are accessible to visa applicants. To the extent 
2  guidance has been issued, it has been confusing, contradictory, in conflict with the terms of the 
3 
Proclamation, or seemingly designed to result in the denial of meritorious applications. Such 
4 
guidance also has failed to provide for a mechanism by which individuals may “demonstrate”—
5 
as the Proclamation says they must—that they meet the eligibility criteria described in the 
6 
Proclamation. Id. 
7 
3.  Immediately  after  the  Proclamation  first  went  fully  into  effect  in  December  2017, 
8 
thousands of individuals, including many plaintiffs in this action, reported receiving blanket, 
9 
boilerplate denials of both visas and waivers, most before ever having had an opportunity to apply 
10 
for a waiver or to “demonstrate” their eligibility. Individuals denied waivers include those who 
11 
had previously been informed by U.S. consular officials that their visas had been approved. Others 
12 
were informed that their eligibility for a waiver is being considered, but have been waiting for 
13 
months or more than a year without a decision in their cases. Both public reports and the latest 
14 
15  government statistics illustrate that the number of waiver grants has been “a minuscule percentage” 
16  of those eligible for visas. Trump v. Hawaii, 585 U.S. ___, 138 S. Ct. 2392, 2431 (2018) (Breyer, 
17  J., dissenting). By all indications, the waiver process has been a fraud. See, e.g., Ex. B, Decl. of 
18 
Christopher  Richardson,  Esq.  (“Richardson  Decl.”),  Alharbi  v.  Miller,  No.  1:18-cv-02435 
19 
(E.D.N.Y. filed Apr. 25, 2018), ECF No. 24-2.      
20 
4.  Plaintiffs and putative class members are U.S. citizens, lawful permanent residents, and 
21 
Iranian, Libyan, Somali, Syrian, and Yemeni foreign nationals whose visa applications have been 
22 
denied or stalled by the government’s failure to provide fair and meaningful access to case-by-
23 
case waivers. Many have approved visa petitions for their family members; others have family 
24 
members who have applied for immigrant or non-immigrant visas and been summarily denied or 
25 
SECOND AMENDED COMPLAINT - 3 
26 
27 
28 
 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 75   Filed 02/23/19   Page 4 of 68
  
1  indefinitely stalled; and others have applied for business-related or extraordinary ability visas to 
2  the United States. All seek entry to the United States to be reunited with their families or because 
3 
of significant business or professional relationships in the United States.  
4 
5.  Based upon all available data and information, Defendants have adopted a policy or 
5 
practice of not instituting an orderly waiver process through which individuals may “demonstrate,” 
6 
as stated in the Proclamation, their eligibility for a case-by-case waiver. Ex. A, § 3(c). 
7 
6.  Defendants have further adopted a policy or practice of not providing information about 
8 
the waiver process and have thereby hindered Plaintiffs’ and their family members’ ability to make 
9 
a showing that they meet the relevant criteria.  
10 
7.  Defendants have also adopted a policy or practice of denying or stalling virtually all visa 
11 
issuance and waiver grants under the Proclamation, and have not given consular officials the 
12 
discretion to grant any waivers.  
13 
8.  As  set  forth  below,  the  government’s failure  to  provide  a  meaningful,  orderly,  and 
14 
15  accessible process through which individuals covered by the ban can demonstrate their eligibility 
16  for a waiver violates the Administrative Procedure Act (“APA”) and Plaintiffs’ right to due process 
17  under the Fifth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution.  
18 
9.  Accordingly, Plaintiffs request that this Court order Defendants to provide clear guidance 
19 
and an orderly process by which applicants may demonstrate their eligibility for a waiver; evaluate 
20 
whether applicants previously denied waivers under an unlawful policy should be reconsidered for 
21 
a waiver grant; act on waivers that have been pending for an unreasonable period of time; and give 
22 
full consideration for case-by-case waivers to all visa applicants as set forth in the Proclamation.  
23 
 
24 
 
25 
SECOND AMENDED COMPLAINT - 4 
26 
27 
28 
 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 75   Filed 02/23/19   Page 5 of 68
  
1  CLASS DEFINITION 
2  10.  Plaintiffs bring this case as a class action under Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 23(a) and 
3 
(b), on behalf of the following two subclasses: (i) the “Family Member Class” and (ii) the “Visa 
4 
Applicant Class.” 
5 
11.  The Family Member Class is comprised of United States citizens and lawful permanent 
6 
residents with approved family-based visa petitions or whose family members have applied for 
7 
visa categories covered by the ban, and whose family members have been or will be refused 
8 
pursuant to the Proclamation without an opportunity to apply for and be meaningfully considered 
9 
for a waiver or are awaiting adjudication of a waiver. 
10 
12.  The Visa Applicant Class is comprised of Iranian, Libyan, Somali, Syrian, and Yemeni 
11 
nationals who have applied for immigrant or nonimmigrant visas that have been or will be refused 
12 
pursuant to the Proclamation without the opportunity to apply for and be meaningfully considered 
13 
for a waiver or who are awaiting adjudication of a waiver. 
14 
15  JURISDICTION, VENUE, AND INTRADISTRICT ASSIGNMENT 
16  13.  Jurisdiction is proper under 28 U.S.C. § 1331 (federal question), 28 U.S.C. § 1361 
17  (Mandamus and Venue Act of 1962), 5 U.S.C. § 702 (APA), and 28 U.S.C. § 2201 (Declaratory 
18 
Judgment Act). The United States has waived its sovereign immunity pursuant to 5 U.S.C. § 702. 
19 
This Court may grant declaratory and injunctive relief pursuant to 5 U.S.C. § 702, 28 U.S.C. § 
20 
1651, and 28 U.S.C. §§ 2201–2202.  
21 
14.  Venue is proper in the Northern District of California under 28 U.S.C. § 1391(e) because 
22 
Defendants are officers or employees of the United States acting in their official capacities and 
23 
agencies of the United States; some Plaintiffs reside in this judicial district; and no real property 
24 
is involved in this action. Plaintiffs have exhausted all administrative remedies. 
25 
SECOND AMENDED COMPLAINT - 5 
26 
27 
28 
 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 75   Filed 02/23/19   Page 6 of 68
  
1  15.  Intradistrict assignment is proper in the San Francisco Division because a substantial part 
2  of the events or omissions that give rise to the claim occurred in San Francisco and Napa Counties.  
3 
Civil L. R. 3-2(c), (d). 
4 
PARTIES 
5 
I.  Plaintiffs 
6 
16.  Plaintiff Tannaz Toloubeydokhti is a U.S. citizen residing in San Diego, California. She 
7 
seeks to be reunited with her parents, for whom she has an approved family-based immigrant visa 
8 
petition.   
9 
17.  Plaintiffs Fathollah Tolou Beydokhti and Behnaz Malekghaeini are Iranian nationals 
10 
residing in Iran. Mr. Tolou Beydokhti and Ms. Malekghaeini have pending immigrant visas based 
11 
on Ms. Toloubeydokhti’s approved family-based immigrant visa petitions.   
12 
18.  Plaintiff Afrooz Kharazmi is a U.S. citizen residing in Loveland, Ohio. She seeks to be 
13 
reunited with her sister, for whom she has an approved family-based visa petition. 
14 
15  19.  Plaintiff Afshan Alamshah Zadeh is an Iranian national residing in Iran. Ms. Alamshah 
16  Zadeh has a pending immigrant visa based on Ms. Kharazmi’s approved family-based immigrant 
17  visa petition.  
18 
20.  Plaintiff Dr. Najib Adi is a U.S. citizen residing in Bristow, Virginia. He seeks to be 
19 
reunited with his Syrian mother, for whom he has an approved family-based visa petition. He has 
20 
been awaiting adjudication of her eligibility for a waiver for more than a year.  
21 
21.  Plaintiff Ismail Alghazali is a U.S. citizen currently residing in Djibouti. He had an 
22 
approved family-based petition for his Yemeni wife, but her visa application was denied at her 
23 
interview in Djibouti in December 2017 and she was not considered for a waiver. He is separated 
24 
from his wife and infant son, whom he wishes to bring home with him to the United States. 
25 
SECOND AMENDED COMPLAINT - 6 
26 
27 
28 
 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 75   Filed 02/23/19   Page 7 of 68
  
1  22.  Plaintiff Malik Almathil is a U.S. citizen residing in New York City. He had an approved 
2  family-based petition for his Yemeni wife, who was told at her interview on July 31, 2017 that her 
3 
visa was approved. Shortly after the Proclamation went into effect in December 2017, she received 
4 
a boilerplate letter denying her a waiver and revoking her visa approval. He seeks to be reunited 
5 
with his wife.  
6 
23.  Plaintiff Khalil Ali Nagi is a U.S. citizen residing in Schenectady, New York with his four-
7 
year-old U.S. citizen daughter. He has an approved family-based petition for his Yemeni wife, 
8 
who had her interview in Djibouti in October 2017. She was told at her interview that her visa 
9 
would be approved, but in March 2018 her visa was denied and she was informed that she would 
10 
not be considered for a waiver. Mr. Ali Nagi seeks to be reunited with his wife.   
11 
24.  Plaintiff Hezam Alarqaban is a lawful permanent resident of the United States residing in 
12 
Oakland, California. He seeks to be reunited with his Yemeni wife and eleven children, for whom 
13 
he has approved family-based visa petitions and who had been issued visas that were later revoked. 
14 
15  He is awaiting adjudication of his family’s eligibility for a waiver.  
16  25.  Plaintiff Abdurraouf Gseaa is a U.S. citizen residing in Houston, Texas. He seeks to be 
17  reunited with his Libyan wife, for whom he has an approved family-based visa petition. He is 
18 
awaiting adjudication of her eligibility for a waiver.  
19 
26.  Plaintiff Sudi Wardere is a U.S. citizen residing in Kirkland, Washington. She seeks to be 
20 
reunited with her Somali husband, for whom she has an approved family-based visa petition. Ms. 
21 
Wardere is awaiting adjudication of her husband’s eligibility for a waiver.   
22 
27.  Plaintiff Khadija Aden is a lawful permanent resident of the United States residing in 
23 
Seattle, Washington. She seeks to be reunited with her son, who was born and has lived his entire 
24 
life in Ethiopia, and for whom she has an approved family-based petition.  
25 
SECOND AMENDED COMPLAINT - 7 
26 
27 
28 
 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 75   Filed 02/23/19   Page 8 of 68
  
1  28.  Plaintiff Soheil Vazehrad is a U.S. citizen residing in Napa, California. He seeks to be 
2  reunited with his fiancée, for whom he has an approved K1 fiancé visa petition.   
3 
29.  Plaintiff Atefehossadat Motavaliabyazani is an Iranian national residing in Iran. Ms. 
4 
Motavaliabyazani has a pending nonimmigrant visa based on Mr. Vazehrad’s approved K1 fiancé 
5 
visa petition. 
6

15  provide clear guidance and an accessible process for submitting applications.

17  Plaintiffs know of no conflict between their interests and those of the Class. Plaintiffs seek the 
18 
same relief as other members of the Class, namely that the Court order Defendants to: (a) provide 
19 
clear guidance and an orderly process by which applicants may demonstrate their eligibility for a 
20 
waiver; (b) evaluate whether applicants previously denied waivers under an unlawful policy should 
21 
be reconsidered for a waiver grant; (c) act on waivers that have been pending for an unreasonable 
22 
period of time; and (d) give full consideration for case-by-case waivers to all visa applicants as set 
23 
forth in the Proclamation.  
24 
25 
SECOND AMENDED COMPLAINT - 60 
26 
27 
28 
 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 75   Filed 02/23/19   Page 61 of 68
  
1  309.   (a) order Defendants to immediately cease their unlawful policy and/or practice of refusing 
2  to receive or consider requests for waivers under the Proclamation for all visa applicants; (b) 
3 
provide an orderly process by which applicants may demonstrate their eligibility for a waiver; and 
4 
(c) give full consideration for case-by-case waivers to all visa applicants as set forth in the 
5 
Proclamation. In defending their own rights, the individual Plaintiffs will defend the rights of all 
6 
Class members fairly and adequately. Plaintiffs are represented by counsel with deep knowledge 
7 
of immigration law and civil rights law and with extensive experience litigating complex cases 
8 
and class actions. Counsel have the requisite level of expertise to adequately prosecute this case 
9 
on behalf of Plaintiffs and the Class. 
10 
310.  The Class satisfies Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(b)(2) because Defendants have 
11 
acted on grounds generally applicable to the Class. Thus, final injunctive and declaratory relief is 
12 
appropriate with respect to the Class as a whole.  
13 
CLAIMS FOR RELIEF 
14 
15  FIRST CLAIM FOR RELIEF 
(Violation of Administrative Procedure Act)  
16   
311.  Plaintiffs repeat and incorporate by reference each and every allegation contained in the 
17 
preceding paragraphs as if fully set forth herein. 
18 
312.  The  APA  prohibits  federal  agency  action  that is  “arbitrary,  capricious,  an  abuse  of 
19 
discretion, or otherwise not in accordance with law,” or is conducted “without observance of 
20 
procedure required by law.” 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(A) and (D). 
21 
313.  Defendants have either failed to promulgate guidance or have promulgated guidance that 
22 
23  is arbitrary and capricious on its face in that it contradicts the terms of the Proclamation and 
24  provides conflicting information to both consular officials and applicants. 
25 
SECOND AMENDED COMPLAINT - 61 
26 
27 
28 
 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 75   Filed 02/23/19   Page 62 of 68
  
1  314.  Defendants have further failed to follow their own policies and procedures and have put in 
2  place a waiver process in which applicants are denied waivers without ever receiving notice or an 
3 
opportunity to apply, applicants are denied waivers without having had a consular interview since 
4 
the time the Proclamation went into effect, applicants are denied waivers in a manner that 
5 
contravenes well-established regulations including 22 C.F.R. §§ 41.121 and 42.81 and the Foreign 
6 
Affairs Manual, and applicants’ visa and waiver applications are indefinitely stalled. 
7 
315.  Defendants have also failed to follow their own stated policy by failing to create an orderly 
8 
process for waiver applications and by failing to consider all visa applicants for a waiver.  
9 
316.  In failing to comply with their own procedures and policies, Defendants’ actions are 
10 
arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, or otherwise not in accordance with law, in violation 
11 
of the APA, 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(A).  
12 
317.  Because Defendants’ actions violate their own procedures and policies, they should be set 
13 
aside. See United States ex rel. Accardi v. Shaughnessy, 347 U.S. 260 (1954). 
14 
15  318.  Defendants’ violations of these laws have harmed and continue to harm Plaintiffs and 
16  proposed Class members by indefinitely denying them access to their families and to economic 
17  and professional opportunities. 
18  SECOND CLAIM FOR RELIEF 
(Violation of Procedural Due Process under the Fifth Amendment) 
19 
 
319.  Plaintiffs repeat and incorporate by reference each and every allegation contained in the 
20 
preceding paragraphs as if fully set forth herein. 
21 
320.  The Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment prohibits the federal government from 
22 
23  depriving individuals of their fundamental rights without due process of law.  
24 
25 
SECOND AMENDED COMPLAINT - 62 
26 
27 
28 
 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 75   Filed 02/23/19   Page 63 of 68
  
1  321.  Family Member Plaintiffs’ fundamental rights include their right to the "integrity of the 
2  family unit." Stanley v. Illinois, 405 U.S. 645, 651 (1972). This includes a cognizable liberty 
3 
interest in their family members’ ability to travel to the United States. See Bustamante v. Mukasey, 
4 
531 F.3d 1059, 1062 (9th Cir. 2008); see also Kerry v. Din, 135 S.Ct. 2128, 2139 (2018) (Kennedy, 
5 
J., concurring); Cardenas v. United States, 826 F.3d 1164, 1167 (9th Cir. 2016) (noting that J. 
6 
Kennedy’s concurrence in Din is controlling). 
7 
322.  Congress has granted statutory rights and prescribed procedures applicable to prospective 
8 
immigrants and non-immigrants. Due process rights attach to those statutory rights, which create 
9 
cognizable liberty and property interests for both Family Member Plaintiffs and Visa Applicant 
10 
Plaintiffs. See Lanza v. Ashcroft, 389 F.3d 917, 927 (9th Cir. 2004) (“The due process afforded 
11 
aliens stems from those statutory rights granted by Congress and the principle that ‘[m]inimum 
12 
due process rights attach to statutory rights.’”) (alteration in original) (quoting Dia v. Ashcroft, 353 
13 
F.3d 228, 239 (3d Cir. 2003). Those interests include reliance interests on the basis of which 
14 
15  Plaintiffs have spent significant resources. See Perry v. Sindermann, 408 U.S. 593, 601 (1972) 
16  (mutually explicit expectations give rise to property interests).  
17  323.  The “very essence” of due process is the “protection of the individual against arbitrary 
18 
action.” Bd. of Regents of State Colls. v. Roth, 408 U.S. 564, 584 (1972). Any deprivation of liberty 
19 
and property interests must, at the very least, have a rational basis.   
20 
324.  The waiver process Defendants have implemented is inherently arbitrary and has deprived 
21 
Plaintiffs of even the most minimal process that attaches to the statutory benefits conferred on 
22 
them by Congress. By not allowing them or their family members the opportunity to apply or be 
23 
meaningfully considered for a waiver, Defendants have deprived them of any opportunity to show 
24 
that they meet the eligibility criteria for visa categories for which they or their family members are 
25 
SECOND AMENDED COMPLAINT - 63 
26 
27 
28 
 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 75   Filed 02/23/19   Page 64 of 68
  
1  eligible by statute. In doing so, Defendants have deprived Plaintiffs of protected liberty and 
2  property interests without due process of law. 
3 
325.  Defendants’ actions have therefore violated Plaintiffs’ right to procedural due process.   
4 
326.  Defendants’ procedural due process violations have harmed and continue to harm Plaintiffs 
5 
and proposed Class members by indefinitely denying them access to their families and to economic 
6 
and research opportunities. 
7 
THIRD CLAIM FOR RELIEF 
8  (Violation of Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment) 
9  327.  Plaintiffs repeat and incorporate by reference each and every allegation contained in the 
10  preceding paragraphs as if set forth fully herein. 
11 
328.  The Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment of the U.S. Constitution guarantees all 
12 
individuals equal protection under the law. 
13 
329.  In Trump v. Hawaii, the Supreme Court relied centrally on the asserted existence of a 
14 
meaningful waiver process to find that the plaintiffs were unlikely to succeed on the merits of their 
15 
constitutional claims. See 585 U.S. ___, 138 S. Ct. 2392, 2422-23 (2018). In the absence of a 
16 
meaningful waiver process, Plaintiffs are being denied visas and waivers or are having their 
17 
applications indefinitely stalled based solely on their national origin or religion, without any 
18 
rational basis.  
19 
330.  The  absence  of  a  meaningful  waiver  process  and  the  blanket  denials  of  waivers  to 
20 
applicants from banned countries, without the opportunity to demonstrate their eligibility for a 
21 
waiver from the Proclamation, amount to intentional discrimination based on national origin or 
22 
23  religion, without any lawful justification.  
24  331.  Defendants’ conduct violates the Fifth Amendment’s guarantee of equal protection.  
25 
SECOND AMENDED COMPLAINT - 64 
26 
27 
28 
 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 75   Filed 02/23/19   Page 65 of 68
  
1  332.  Defendants’ equal protection violations have harmed and continue to harm Plaintiffs and 
2  proposed Class members by indefinitely denying them access to their families and to economic 
3 
and research opportunities. 
4 
FOURTH CLAIM FOR RELIEF 
(Mandamus) 
5 
 
6  333.  Plaintiffs repeat and incorporate by reference each and every allegation contained in the 
7  preceding paragraphs as if fully set forth herein. 
8  334.  The APA requires agencies to “proceed to conclude a matter presented” to the agency 
9  “within a reasonable time.” 5 U.S.C. § 555(b).  
10 
335.  Defendants have a non-discretionary duty to develop guidance on the waiver process and 
11 
to receive and fully and fairly adjudicate applicants’ requests for waivers under the Proclamation 
12 
within a reasonable time.  
13 
336.  The Proclamation first went fully into effect on December 4, 2017. More than a year has 
14 
passed and Defendants have nonetheless failed to develop meaningful guidance and a waiver 
15 
process by which every individual applicant may receive full consideration for a waiver. 
16 
337.  Further, many individual Plaintiffs in this action have been awaiting decisions on their visa 
17 
and waiver applications for several months up to well over a year. In failing to adjudicate their 
18 
applications, Defendants have failed to act “within a reasonable time” in violation of the APA. 
19 
338.  In addition, Plaintiffs whose family members were told at the interview that their visas 
20 
would be approved or who were issued visas that were later revoked pursuant to the Proclamation 
21 
22  are entitled to immediate issuance of visas. This is because the approval of their visas was reversed 
23  in contravention to the explicit terms of the Proclamation and agency guidance, which provides 
24 
25 
SECOND AMENDED COMPLAINT - 65 
26 
27 
28 
 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 75   Filed 02/23/19   Page 66 of 68
  
1  that no visas will be revoked. See Alharbi v. Miller, No. 1:18-cv-02435 (E.D.N.Y. filed April 25, 
2  2018).  
3 
339.  Because  there  are  no  other  adequate  remedies  available  to  Plaintiffs,  mandamus  is 
4 
appropriate. See 5 U.S.C. § 704. 
5 
PRAYER FOR RELIEF 
6 
WHEREFORE, Plaintiffs pray that this Court: 
7 
1.  Declare that Defendants’ actions in implementing and enforcing Section 3(c) of the 
8 
Proclamation have been arbitrary, capricious, and otherwise contrary to law; 
9 
2.  Declare that Defendants’ actions in implementing and enforcing Section 3(c) of the 
10 
Proclamation have violated Plaintiffs’ procedural due process and equal protection rights 
11 
under the Fifth Amendment; 
12 
3.  Order Defendants to issue guidance and develop a waiver process that does not violate the 
13 
APA or the constitutional guarantees of due process and equal protection and that provides 
14 
15  meaningful consideration to every individual visa applicant; 
16  4.  Order Defendants to evaluate whether individual and Class member applicants previously 
17  denied waivers under an unlawful process should be reconsidered for a waiver grant; 
18 
5.  Order Defendants to act on waivers that have been pending for an unreasonable period of 
19 
time; 
20 
6.  Award Plaintiffs costs of suit and reasonable attorney’s fees under the Equal Access to 
21 
Justice Act and any other applicable law; and 
22 
7.  Grant such other and further relief as this Court deems equitable, just, and proper. 
23

24         Washington, DC

COMPLAINT - 1 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 1   Filed 03/13/18   Page 2 of 45
 
1        -against-            
          
2  DONALD J. TRUMP, as President of the United 
States of America; JEFFERSON BEAUREGARD  
3 
SESSIONS III, in his official capacity as Attorney  
General of the United States; U.S. DEPARTMENT  
4 
OF JUSTICE; KIRSTJEN NIELSEN, in her official  
capacity as Secretary of Homeland Security; U.S.  
5 
DEPARTMENT OF HOMELAND SECURITY;  
REX W. TILLERSON, in his official capacity as  
6 
Secretary of State; U.S. DEPARTMENT OF STATE;  
DAN COATS, in his official capacity as  
7 
Director of National Intelligence; OFFICE OF THE 
8  DIRECTOR OF NATIONAL INTELLIGENCE  
 
9          Defendants. 
 
10  INTRODUCTION 
11 
1.  Mania Pour Aghdasi is a U.S. citizen residing in California. In September 2016, Ms. 
12 
Aghdasi’s brother passed away after battling brain cancer in the house in which her father lived 
13 
in Iran. Ms. Aghdasi is her father’s last remaining family member. She assisted her father, a 78-
14 
year-old Iranian national, in applying for a visitor’s visa so they could be together in their grief. 
15 
During the long 14 months that followed, Ms. Aghdasi repeatedly contacted the U.S. Embassy, 
16 
her congressional representatives, the State Department, the White House—anyone who would 
17 
listen—to get her father’s visa approved as his health deteriorated. Ms. Aghdasi’s father died on 
18 
December 24, 2017, waiting for his visa to be issued. Two weeks later, his visa application was 
19 
denied pursuant to the Presidential Proclamation that established the latest travel ban. At no 
20 
point did anyone consider Ms. Aghdasi’s father for a waiver from the travel ban. Nonetheless 
21 
his visa was denied. Ms. Aghdasi’s story is emblematic of the destruction and tragedy that has 
22 
23  been wrought by the Proclamation’s reckless implementation, but her experience is sadly not 
24  uncommon.  
25 
COMPLAINT - 2 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 1   Filed 03/13/18   Page 3 of 45
 
1  2.  Plaintiffs and proposed class members are American citizens, U.S. lawful permanent 
2  residents, and foreign nationals who have approved visa petitions, or who have assisted family 
3 
members with filing for U.S. visas, and who seek entry to the United States to be reunited with 
4 
their American families or fulfill significant U.S. business relations.  
5 
3.  In 2017, President Donald J. Trump attempted to institute three travel bans via executive 
6 
order and presidential proclamation. Each ban applied mostly to Muslim-majority countries. The 
7 
first two versions were struck down by federal district and appellate courts. The constitutionality 
8 
of the third travel ban is currently being litigated at the U.S. Supreme Court. On December 4, 
9 
2017, the Court issued a decision allowing the third travel ban to be implemented while the case 
10 
was heard on its merits.  
11 
4.  On December 8, 2017, Defendants began implementing the third version of the travel 
12 
ban in a way that violates the Administrative Procedure Act (“APA”), the Immigration and 
13 
Nationality Act (“INA”), and Plaintiffs’ right to due process under the Fifth Amendment to the 
14 
15  U.S. Constitution. The Presidential Proclamation (“Proclamation”) that established this ban 
16  specifically states that “case-by-case waivers” may be granted by consular officers under a non-
17  exclusive list of circumstances for visa applicants from the banned countries. Nonetheless, in 
18 
direct contravention of the terms of the Proclamation, Defendants have refused to consider such 
19 
waivers and have instead issued blanket denials of visas, regardless of personal circumstances 
20 
and without giving applicants the opportunity to argue their cases, thereby violating the APA, 
21 
the INA, and Plaintiffs’ right to Fifth Amendment due process.  
22 
5.  These claims are backed up by numbers published by Defendants themselves: State 
23 
Department has revealed that, as of March 6, 2018, only about a hundred waivers had been 
24 
granted to visa applicants from the banned countries, a rejection rate of more than 98%.  
25 
COMPLAINT - 3 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 1   Filed 03/13/18   Page 4 of 45
 
1  6.  Defendants’ unlawful and discriminatory actions have shattered Plaintiffs’ lives and 
2  their prospects for being reunited with their loved ones as well as the lives and reunification 
3 
prospects of the scores of similarly situated families and individuals they seek to represent 
4 
through  this  action.  They  seek  this  Court’s  intervention  to  cease  visa  denials  due  to  the 
5 
Proclamation.  Such  intervention  is  needed  to  prevent  ongoing  and  future  harm  to  such 
6 
applicants and to protect the integrity of the U.S. visa process.  
7 
7.  At issue in this suit is Section 3 of the Proclamation, which allows for case-by-case 
8 
waivers  from  the  Proclamation  for  visa  applicants  from  the  countries  banned  by  the 
9 
Proclamation. 
10 
 
11 
JURISDICTION, VENUE, AND INTRADISTRICT ASSIGNMENT 
12 
8.  Jurisdiction is proper under 28 U.S.C. § 1331 (federal question), 28 U.S.C. § 1361 
13 
(Mandamus and Venue Act of 1962), 5 U.S.C. § 702 (APA), and 28 U.S.C. § 220 (Declaratory 
14 
15  Judgment Act). The United States has waived its sovereign immunity pursuant to 5 U.S.C. § 
16  702. This Court may grant declaratory and injunctive relief pursuant to 5 U.S.C. § 702, 28 
17  U.S.C. § 1651, and 28 U.S.C. § 2201–2202. A claim for attorney’s fees will be brought pursuant 
18 
to 5 U.S.C. § 504 and 28 U.S.C. § 2412(d).  
19 
9.  Venue is proper in the Northern District of California under 28 U.S.C. § 1391(e) because 
20 
Defendants are officers or employees of the United States acting in their official capacities and 
21 
agencies of the United States, many Plaintiffs reside in this judicial district, and no real property 
22 
is involved in this action.  Plaintiffs have exhausted all administrative remedies. 
23 
24 
25 
COMPLAINT - 4 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 1   Filed 03/13/18   Page 5 of 45
 
1  10.  Intradistrict assignment is proper in the San Francisco Division because a substantial 
2  part of the events or omissions that give rise to the claim occurred in San Francisco and Napa 
3 
Counties.  Civil L. R. 3-2(c), (d). 
4 
 
5 
PARTIES 
6 
11.  Plaintiff Soheil Vazehrad is a U.S. citizen, residing in Napa, California. 
7

9 
approved K1 fiancée visa petition. 
10

11 
$500,000.00 in CMB Infrastructure Investment Group XIV, L.P., located in San Bernardino, 
12 
California.  
13 
15.  Plaintiff Mr. Behnam Babalou has an approved immigrant visa petition based on his 
14 
15  investments and significant business ties in CMB Infrastructure Investment Group XIV, L.P.  
16  16.  Plaintiff Hoda Mehrabi Mohammad Abadi is an Iranian national residing in Iran who 
17  and has an approved immigrant visa petition based on her $500,000.00 investment in Kimpton 
18 
Hotels & Restaurants in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. 
19

20 
who has an approved immigrant visa petition based on his extensive record of achievements as 
21 
an alien with extraordinary ability. 
22 
18.  Plaintiff Dr. Ehsan Heidaryan is an Iranian national, currently residing in Brazil, who 
23 
has an approved immigrant visa petition based on his extensive record of achievements as an 
24 
alien with extraordinary ability.  
25 
COMPLAINT - 5 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 1   Filed 03/13/18   Page 6 of 45
 
1  19.  Plaintiff Najmeh Maharlouei is an Iranian national currently residing in Shiraz, Iran, 
2  who has an approved immigrant visa petition based on her extensive record of achievements and 
3 
the fact that her work is in the U.S. national interest. 
4

5

12 
California.  
13 
25.  Plaintiffs Roghayeh Azizikoutenaei and Hojjatollah Azizikoutenaei are Iranian nationals 
14

Rockville, Maryland.

22 
residing in Iran. 
23 
30.  Mr. Tedrick and Ms. Farnoodian-Tedrick assisted Mr. Farnoudian and Ms. Emami with 
24 
applying for tourist visas. 
25 
COMPLAINT - 6 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 1   Filed 03/13/18   Page 7 of 45
 
1  31.  Plaintiff Tannaz Toloubeydokhti is a U.S. citizen who resides in San Diego, California.  
2  32.  Plaintiffs Fathollah Tolou Beydokhti and Behnaz Malekghaeini are Iranian nationals 
3 
residing in Iran. 
4 
33.  Mr.  Beydokhti  and  Ms.  Malekghaeini  have  pending  immigrant  visas  based  on  Ms. 
5 
Toloubeydokhti’s approved family-based immigrant visa petitions.   
6 
34.  Plaintiff Maral Charkhtab Tabrizi is a U.S. lawful permanent resident living in Tempe, 
7 
Arizona, who is married to a U.S. citizen and has just given birth to her first child.  
8 
35.  Plaintiffs  Zahra  Rouzbehani  and  Bahram  Charkhtab  Tabrizi  are  Iranian  nationals 
9 
residing in Iran. 
10 
36.  Ms. Tabrizi assisted her parents, Ms. Rouzbehani and Mr. Charkhtab Tabrizi, with filing 
11

49.  On September 24, 2017, President Trump signed the third version of the travel ban, 
10 
Presidential Proclamation 9645, entitled “Enhancing Vetting Capabilities and Processes for 
11 
Detecting Attempted Entry Into the United States by Terrorists or Other Public-Safety Threats.”

Presidential  Proclamation  9645,  82  Fed.  Reg.  45161  (Sept.  27,  2017).  (Exhibit  A)  The 
13 
Proclamation provides for discretionary case-by-case waivers from a now-indefinite travel ban 
14 
15  on nationals of the six Muslim-majority countries. 
16  50.  Affected states and individuals immediately brought suit against the Proclamation in 
17  federal district court in Hawaii and Maryland, seeking to block implementation of the travel 
18 
ban. On October 17, 2017, the Hawaii court granted a nationwide temporary restraining order 
19 
and, the following day, the Maryland court issued a nationwide preliminary injunction.

21 
Appeal. It also requested the U.S. Supreme Court to issue a stay of the Hawaii and Maryland 
22 
courts’ decisions blocking the Proclamation’s implementation pending disposition of its appeals 
23 
of  those  decisions  in  the  circuit  courts.  The  U.S.  Supreme  Court  granted  that  request  on

4 
preliminary injunction order but stayed its decision pending review by the U.S. Supreme Court.

II.  Relevant Law 
7 
58.  Section 3 of the Proclamation contains a subsection entitled “Waivers,” which states: 
8 
Notwithstanding the suspensions of and limitations on entry set 
9  forth in section 2 of this proclamation, a consular officer, or the 
Commissioner,  United  States  Customs  and  Border  Protection 
10  (CBP), or the Commissioner’s designee, as appropriate, may, in 
their discretion, grant waivers on a case-by-case basis to permit 
11 
the  entry  of  foreign  nationals  for  whom  entry  is  otherwise 
suspended or limited if such foreign nationals demonstrate that 
12 
waivers would be appropriate and consistent with subsections (i) 
through (iv) of this subsection [laying out waiver standards].  
13 
 
82 Fed. Reg. at 45167. 
14 
15  59.  The Proclamation explains that a waiver may be granted if, in a consular officer’s or 
16  CBP’s discretion, a foreign national has demonstrated that (1) a denial of entry “would cause the 
17  foreign national undue hardship”; (2) his or her “entry would not pose a threat to the national 
18 
security or public safety of the United States”; and (3) his or her “entry would be in the national 
19 
interest.” 82 Fed. Reg. at 45168. 
20 
60.  The Proclamation then specifies that while “case-by-case waivers may not be granted 
21 
categorically,” they “may be appropriate, subject to the limitations, conditions, and requirements 
22 
set forth” in subsection (c), “in individual circumstances ….” Id. It proceeds to give a number of 
23 
examples  of  such  circumstances  under  which  issuance  of  a  waiver  may  be  appropriate, 
24 
including:  
25

impair that activity;

fees, travel costs, and medical fees, for herself and three family members, all of which she will 
11 
be unable to recoup. 
12 
119.  Plaintiff Afrooz Kharazmi and Plaintiff Afshan Alamshah Zadeh waited in line for more 
13 
than 12 years for Ms. Alamshah Zadeh’s priority date to become current, enduring years of 
14 
15  hardship, separation, and sacrifice. Ms. Alamshah Zadeh’s entire family are American citizens 
16  residing in the United States, and she is therefore at risk of permanently losing the ability to visit 
17  any member of her family and being left permanently alone in Iran. The sisters have also paid 
18 
thousands of dollars in attorney’s fees, filing fees, travel costs, and medical fees, which they 
19 
cannot recover. 
20 
120.  Plaintiff Bamshad Azizi and his parents, Roghayeh and Hojjatollah Azizikoutenaei, have 
21 
suffered and are suffering significant emotional distress at their ongoing separation.  Mrs. 
22 
Azizikoutenaei has been suffering from cancer for the last year and Mr. and Ms. Azizikoutenaei 
23 
both recently underwent surgeries. All the family wants is to be together, but, because the travel 
24 
ban is of an indeterminate length, and Mr. and Mrs. Azizikoutenaei are quite weak after their 
25 
COMPLAINT - 34 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 1   Filed 03/13/18   Page 35 of 45
 
1  illnesses and surgeries, they are unsure that they will ever get to be reunited. This prospect is 
2  also causing Mr. Azizi and his parents ongoing and significant emotional distress. The family 
3 
have paid thousands of dollars in attorney’s fees, filing fees, and travel costs, which they will be 
4 
unable to recoup.  
5 
121.  Plaintiff Clyde Jean Tedrick II and Plaintiff Mitra Farnoodian-Tedrick cancelled their 
6 
wedding and lost $3,976.76 because of Defendants’ denial of Plaintiff Farajollah Farnoudian 
7 
and Plaintiff Farangis Emami’s case. They have all suffered considerable stress in connection 
8 
with the wedding and have lost, perhaps permanently, an experience that everyone should get to 
9 
enjoy: celebrating a wedding with one’s parents. They have also paid thousands of dollars in 
10 
attorney’s fees, filing fees, and travel costs, which they cannot recoup.  
11 
122.  Plaintiff Tannaz Toloubeydokhti has suffered significant emotional distress as she has 
12 
been deprived of the opportunity to have her parents, Mr. Fathollah Tolou Beydokhti and Ms. 
13 
Behnaz Malekghaeini present during her pregnancy. They are also at risk of missing the birth of 
14 
15  Ms. Toloubeydokhti’s child. These experiences are ones none of them can ever get back and this 
16  loss is irreparable. Ms. Toloubeydokhti is also at risk of enduring a significant financial burden, 
17  as she had hoped that her parents would assist her with childcare for her newborn. She may have 
18 
to seek hired help, an expensive prospect. Ms. Toloubeydokhti and her parents have also paid 
19 
thousands of dollars in attorney’s fees, filing fees, and travel costs, which they will be unable to 
20 
recoup.  
21 
123.  Plaintiff Maral Charkhtab Tabrizi has suffered significant emotional distress as she was 
22 
deprived  of  the  opportunity  to  have  her  parents,  Plaintiffs  Zahra  Rouzbehani  and  Bahram 
23 
Charkhtab Tabrizi, present during her pregnancy. She also suffered increased physical pain and 
24 
suffering, as she has a connective tissue disorder with associated pain that would have been 
25 
COMPLAINT - 35 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 1   Filed 03/13/18   Page 36 of 45
 
1  lessened with the assistance of her parents. Additionally, Ms. Rouzbehani and Mr. Charkhtab 
2  Tabrizi missed the birth of their first grandchild. This is an experience none of them can never 
3 
get back and their loss is therefore irreparable. Ms. Charkhtab Tabrizi is also at risk of enduring 
4 
a significant financial burden, as she had hoped that her parents would assist her with childcare 
5 
for her newborn. Because Ms. Charkhtab Tabrizi cannot take paid time off, without her parents’ 
6 
assistance, she will have to increase the amount of time she takes off, thereby losing far more 
7 
money  than  she  would  have  had  her  parents  been  present.  Her  unpaid  leave,  potentially 
8 
extended due to Ms. Rouzbehani and Mr. Charkhtab Tabrizi’s absence, may also result in the 
9 
cancellation of her job contract and the loss of her medical benefits, harms that would be 
10 
irreparable. Ms. Charkhtab Tabrizi and her parents have also paid thousands of dollars in 
11 
attorney’s fees, filing fees, and travel costs, which they will be unable to recoup.  
12 
124.  Applicants are told in their denial letters they can apply for visas again. But Defendants 
13 
have no protocols in place and, despite having more than five months to do so, have issued no 
14 
15  guidance to officers or applicants. Thus, applicants will have to pay application fees, buy plane 
16  tickets, make hotel reservations, and pay, again, all of the costs associated with applying for a 
17  visa and traveling to a U.S. embassy to attend yet another interview with no hope of achieving a 
18 
different result. 
19 
125.  As a result, Plaintiffs’ rights continue to be violated and they continue to be separated 
20 
from  their  families,  jobs,  research,  and  investments  on  the  basis  of  the  unlawful  and 
21 
unconstitutional waiver process. 
22 
 
23 
CLASS ALLEGATIONS 
24 
25 
COMPLAINT - 36 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 1   Filed 03/13/18   Page 37 of 45
 
1  126.  Individual Plaintiffs bring this action as a class action pursuant to Federal Rules of Civil 
2  Procedure 23(b)(1) and (b)(2), on behalf of themselves and all other persons similarly situated. 
3 
A class action is proper because the class is so numerous that joinder of all members is 
4 
impractical, this action involves questions of law and fact common to the class, Plaintiffs’ 
5 
claims are typical of the claims of the class, Plaintiffs will fairly and adequately protect the 
6 
interests of the class, and Defendants have acted on grounds that apply generally to the class, so 
7 
that final injunctive relief or corresponding declaratory relief is appropriate with respect to the 
8 
class as a whole. 
9 
127.   In addition to the named plaintiffs, there are many other similarly situated individuals 
10 
who have been denied waivers and visas pursuant to the Proclamation. Each of these similarly 
11 
situated individuals is entitled to bring a complaint for declaratory and injunctive relief to 
12 
prohibit Defendants’ policy, pattern, and practice of denying waivers and visas to applicants 
13 
from banned countries without a good faith consideration of their applications. 
14 
15  128.  The proposed class is defined as follows: 
16  All petitioners and beneficiaries of immigrant or nonimmigrant 
visa petitions that were refused or will be refused pursuant to the 
17  Proclamation without the opportunity to request a waiver of the 
Proclamation  or  that  were  refused  or  will  be  refused  despite 
18 
clearly falling under the examples provided by the Proclamation 
for circumstances under which a waiver may be appropriate. All 
19 
individuals who were or will be considered for a waiver of the 
Proclamation and refused a waiver due to Defendants’ narrow and 
20 
incorrect definition of a “close family member.”  
 
21 
129.  The proposed class meets the requirements of Rule 23(a)(1) because it is so numerous 
22 
that joinder of all members is impracticable. The number of individuals who have been wrongly 
23 
denied  waivers  is  not  known  with  precision  by  Plaintiffs  but  is  easily  ascertainable  by 
24 
Defendants. On any given day, thousands of visa applications are adjudicated at embassies and 
25 
COMPLAINT - 37 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 1   Filed 03/13/18   Page 38 of 45
 
1  consulates abroad. As such, more individuals will become class members in the future, as 
2  Defendants continue to deny applicants a good faith opportunity to request a waiver of the 
3 
Proclamation. The members of the class are ascertainable and identifiable by Defendants. 
4 
130.  The proposed class meets the commonality requirements of Rule 23(a)(2) because all 
5 
proposed class members have been or will be subject to Defendants’ common policy, pattern, 
6 
and practice of refusing to consider applicants for waivers of the Proclamation. Plaintiffs and the 
7 
proposed class share the same legal claims, which include, but are not limited to: whether 
8 
Defendants’ refusal to consider applicants for waivers in good faith and failure to develop 
9 
standards or guidance for consular officers and visa applicants to follow violate the APA, the 
10 
INA, and the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment.  
11 
131.  Similarly, the proposed class meets the typicality requirements of Rule 23(a)(3) because 
12 
the claims of the representative Plaintiffs are typical of the claims of the class as a whole. 
13 
Plaintiffs, as with the class they seek to represent, are all individuals who have been or will be 
14 
15  denied the chance to request a waiver of the Proclamation and who have been or will be stymied 
16  in their attempts to apply by a dearth of guidance from Defendants.  
17  132.  The adequacy requirements of Rule 23(a)(4) are also met. Plaintiffs know of no conflict 
18 
between their interests and those of the proposed class. Plaintiff seek the same relief as other 
19 
members of the class, namely that the Court (a) order Defendants to immediately cease their 
20 
unlawful policy and/or practice of refusing to receive or consider requests for waivers of the 
21 
Proclamation; (b) retract visa denials due to the arbitrary and capricious nature of Defendants’ 
22 
decision to implement the ban without appropriate guidance in place; (c) provide clear guidance 
23 
that defines key words and sets clear standards for consular officers and applicants to use; and 
24 
(d) abide by the terms of the Proclamation and consider case-by-case waivers in good faith. In 
25 
COMPLAINT - 38 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 1   Filed 03/13/18   Page 39 of 45
 
1  defending their own rights, the individual Plaintiffs will defend the rights of all class members 
2  fairly and adequately. Plaintiffs are represented by counsel with deep knowledge of immigration 
3 
law and extensive experience litigating class actions and complex cases. Counsel have the 
4 
requisite level of expertise to adequately prosecute this case on behalf of Plaintiffs and the 
5 
proposed class. 
6 
133.  The proposed class satisfies Rule 23(b)(2) because Defendants have acted on grounds 
7 
generally applicable to the class in refusing to fairly adjudicate waiver requests. Thus, final 
8 
injunctive and declaratory relief is appropriate with respect to the class as a whole.  
9 
 
10 
 
11 
CAUSES OF ACTION 
12 
COUNT ONE 
13 
(Violation of Administrative Procedure Act)  
14 
134.  Plaintiffs repeat and incorporate by reference each and every allegation contained in the 
15 
preceding paragraphs as if fully set forth herein. 
16 
135.  The APA prohibits federal agency action that is “arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of 
17 
discretion, or otherwise not in accordance with law,” or is conducted “without observance of 
18 
procedure required by law.” 5 U.S.C. § 706(2). 
19 
136.  The  INA  prohibits  discrimination  in  the  issuance  of  immigrant  visas  based  on 
20 
nationality,  place  of  birth,  or  place  of  residence.  8  U.S.C.  §  1152(a)(1)(A).  The  INA’s 
21 
22  implementing regulations specify the procedures for issuance or denial of a visa. 22 C.F.R. 
23  42.81; 22 CFR 41.121; 22 C.F.R. § 40.6. Under these regulations, a denial must be based on 
24  legal grounds and made in conformance with the INA.  
25 
COMPLAINT - 39 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 1   Filed 03/13/18   Page 40 of 45
 
1  137.  In denying waivers and visas to Plaintiffs and proposed class members based on their 
2  country of origin or nationality, Defendants have acted arbitrarily, capriciously, and not in 
3 
accordance with the INA.  
4 
138.  Defendants’  actions  have  resulted  in  the  indefinite—and  possibly  permanent—
5 
separation of U.S. citizens and U.S. lawful permanent residents from their family members in 
6 
contravention of Congress’ purpose in enacting the INA: promoting family reunification. This 
7 
conduct is not in accordance with the INA. 
8 
139.  Defendants have discriminated against Plaintiffs and proposed class members based on 
9 
the proscribed grounds in implementing the Proclamation’s waivers provisions. In this respect, 
10 
they have failed to use the discretion granted them by law. They are therefore in violation of the 
11 
APA. 
12 
140.  Defendants have a non-discretionary duty under the Proclamation to develop standards 
13 
to guide visa applicants in compiling their applications for waivers and for consular officers to 
14 
15  reference in adjudicating waiver and visa applications. See 82 Fed. Reg. at 45168. Defendants 
16  have failed to promulgate such guidance and have nonetheless proceeded in denying waivers 
17  and visas. Defendants have also failed to follow existing procedures prescribed by the INA and 
18 
implementing regulations and the Foreign Affairs Manual in issuing these denials. In failing to 
19 
develop or follow any procedures, instead basing their decisions on applicants’ country of origin 
20 
or  nationality,  Defendants  have  conducted  themselves  arbitrarily  and  capriciously  and  in 
21 
contravention of the Proclamation, the INA, and the U.S. Constitution, and they have thus 
22 
violated the APA.   
23 
24 
25 
COMPLAINT - 40 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 1   Filed 03/13/18   Page 41 of 45
 
1  141.  Defendants’ violations of these laws have harmed and continue to harm Plaintiffs and 
2  proposed class members by indefinitely denying them access to their families and to economic 
3 
and research opportunities. 
4 
 
5 
COUNT TWO 
(Violation of Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment) 
6 
142.  Plaintiffs repeat and incorporate by reference each and every allegation contained in the 
7 
8  preceding paragraphs as if fully set forth herein. 
9  143.  The Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment of the U.S. Constitution protects all 
10  individuals from the government denying equal protection of the law. 
11 
144.  The blanket denials of visas to applicants from banned countries without the opportunity 
12 
to argue for a waiver from the Proclamation, together with statements made by Defendants 
13 
concerning their intent and the application of the travel ban, makes clear that Defendants are 
14 
targeting individuals for discriminatory treatment based on their country of origin or nationality, 
15 
without any lawful justification.  
16 
145.  Defendants’  implementation  of  the  waivers  provision  has  a  disparate  impact  on 
17 
applicants from certain countries and of certain nationalities.  
18 
146.  Defendants’  discriminatory  implementation  of  the  waivers  provisions  serves  no 
19 
compelling government interest and is not narrowly tailored.  
20 
147.  Defendants’ conduct violates the Fifth Amendment’s guarantee of equal protection.  
21 
148.  The Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment also prohibits the federal government 
22 
23  from  depriving  individuals  of  their  fundamental  rights  without  due  process  of  law,  i.e., 
24  substantive due process.  
25 
COMPLAINT - 41 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 1   Filed 03/13/18   Page 42 of 45
 
1  149.  Plaintiffs’ fundamental rights include their right to the "integrity of the family unit." 
2  Stanley v. Illinois, 405 U.S. 645, 651 (1972).  
3 
150.  The  implementation  of  the  waiver  provision  of  the  Proclamation  directly  and 
4 
substantially infringes on Plaintiffs’ fundamental rights. 
5 
151.  The Due Process Clause forbids Defendants from infringing on Plaintiffs’ fundamental 
6 
rights unless the infringement is narrowly tailored to serve a compelling governmental interest.  
7 
152.  As  applied,  the  Proclamation’s  waivers  provision  fails  this  test.  It  is  not  narrowly 
8 
tailored to protect national security interests—it operates to block nearly all persons from 
9 
banned countries from entry into the United States, regardless of their relationship to violence or 
10 
terrorism. It is both under- and over-inclusive. 
11 
153.  The Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment guarantees procedural due process 
12 
rights, e.g., the right to fair and impartial processes, even to foreign nationals. Those due process 
13 
rights are implicated by the deprivation of a fundamental liberty interest, e.g., family integrity, 
14 
15  and they may also arise from statute. See Lanza v. Ashcroft, 389 F.3d 917, 927 (9th Cir. 2004) 
16  (“The due process afforded aliens stems from those statutory rights granted by Congress and the 
17  principle  that  ‘minimum  due  process  rights  attach  to  statutory  rights.’”)  (quoting  Dia  v. 
18 
Ashcroft, 353 F.3d 228, 239 (3d Cir. 2003). The INA and its implementing regulations mandate 
19 
various procedures for the processing of visas, procedures which Defendants have failed to 
20 
follow.  
21 
154.  In refusing to consider Plaintiffs’ applications in good faith, Defendants have violated 
22 
Plaintiffs’ Fifth Amendment right to equal protection under the law and to substantive and 
23 
procedural due process.   
24 
25 
COMPLAINT - 42 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 1   Filed 03/13/18   Page 43 of 45
 
1  155.  Defendants’ violations of these laws have harmed and continue to harm Plaintiffs and 
2  proposed class members by indefinitely denying them access to their families and economic and 
3 
research opportunities. 
4 
 
5 
COUNT THREE 
6  (Writ of Mandamus) 
 
7  156.  Plaintiffs repeat and incorporate by reference each and every allegation contained in the 
8  preceding paragraphs as if fully set forth herein. 
9  157.  Defendants owe Plaintiffs and class members a duty to adjudicate in good faith their 
10 
requests for waivers of the Proclamation. The adjudication of waivers and development of 
11 
guidance on such adjudication are clear, non-discretionary duties imposed upon Defendants by 
12 
the INA and implementing regulations and by section 3 of the Proclamation.  
13 
158.  Defendants are unlawfully ignoring Plaintiffs’ requests for waivers of the Proclamation 
14 
and have failed to carry out the adjudicative and administrative functions delegated to them by 
15 
law with regard to Plaintiffs’ cases.  
16 
159.  Defendants’ refusal to consider applicants’ eligibility for waivers on a case-by-case basis 
17 
or  develop  meaningful  guidance  is,  as  a  matter  of  law,  arbitrary,  capricious,  and  not  in 
18 
accordance with the law and is thus violative of the APA. 
19 
160.  Defendants’ policy and practice of denying visa applications and waivers to people of a 
20 
certain country of origin or nationality violates Plaintiffs’ right against discrimination under the 
21 
22  INA and implementing regulations. 
23  161.  Defendants’ discriminatory behavior in issuing blanket denials to visa applicants from 
24  banned countries without consideration of their personal circumstances violates Plaintiffs’ Fifth 
25 
COMPLAINT - 43 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 1   Filed 03/13/18   Page 44 of 45
 
1  Amendment  rights  to  equal  protection  under  the  law  and  substantive  and  procedural  due 
2  process. 
3 
162.  Because  there  are  no  other  adequate  remedies  available  to  Plaintiffs,  mandamus  is 
4 
appropriate. See 5 U.S.C. § 704. 
5 
163.  Defendants’ violation of the law in denying Plaintiffs the opportunity to present waiver 
6 
applications as a matter of course, and thereby refusing to consider waivers on a case-by-case 
7 
basis, is substantially unjustified. Plaintiffs are, therefore, entitled to reasonable attorney’s fees 
8 
under the Equal Access to Justice Act, 28 U.S.C. § 2412.  
9 
 
10 
PRAYER FOR RELIEF 
11 
WHEREFORE, Plaintiffs pray for the following relief: 
12 
1.  A temporary restraining order and/or preliminary and permanent injunction enjoining 
13 
Defendants from denying visa applications due to the Proclamation; 
14 
15  2.  An  order  requiring  Defendants  to  immediately  retract  all  visa  denials  due  to  the 
16  Proclamation and notify applicants that they may apply for a waiver of the Proclamation 
17  without submitting a new visa application, paying associated fees, and attending another 
18 
interview; 
19 
3.  An order requiring Defendants to fulfill their duties by providing clear and consistent 
20 
guidelines for the waiver process, including definitions of key terms, standards for 
21 
applicants to meet, and examples of documents needed to meet those standards;  
22 
4.  An order requiring Defendants to abide by the terms of the Proclamation and consider 
23 
applicants’ waiver applications on a case-by-case basis without discriminating based on 
24 
applicants’ country of origin or nationality; 
25 
COMPLAINT - 44 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 1   Filed 03/13/18   Page 45 of 45
 
1  5.  An order declaring Defendants’ refusal to consider waiver applications in good faith as 
2  violative of the APA, the INA, and the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment; 
3 
6.  An order awarding Plaintiffs costs of suit and reasonable attorney’s fees under the Equal 
4 
Access to Justice Act and any other applicable law; 
5 
7.  Such other and further relief as this Court deems equitable, just, and proper. 
6 
DATED: March 13, 2018 
   
7 
Kent, Washington  
8   
Respectfully Submitted,

FARANGIS EMAMI, et al.,  Case No. 18-cv-01587-JD

Plaintiffs,

v. 
9 
  Re: Dkt. No. 42 
KIRSTJEN NIELSEN, et al., 
10 
Defendants. 
11 
   
12   
a 
tr in
uoro 13  This case is a putative class action brought by thirty-six named plaintiffs against the United 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  States Department of Homeland Security, the Department of State, the agencies for Customs and 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  Border Protection and Citizenship and Immigration Services, and their senior leaders.  Dkt. No. 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  34.  Plaintiffs challenge the government’s conduct in connection with a waiver program that 
S d nr
ee 17  would permit the entry into the United States of foreign nationals banned by Presidential 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  Proclamation 9645.  This order resolves defendants’ motion to dismiss plaintiffs’ complaint, 
19  which was brought under Rule 12(b)(6) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.  Dkt. No. 42. 
20  BACKGROUND 
21  I.  THE LEGAL CONTEXT 
22  The complaint arises out of Presidential Proclamation 9645, “Enhancing Vetting 
23  Capabilities and Processes for Detecting Attempted Entry Into the United States by Terrorists or 
24  Other Public-Safety Threats,” which President Trump signed on September 24, 2017.  82 Fed. 
25  Reg. 45161 (2017) (the “Proclamation”).  The President states that he issued the Proclamation 
26  after ordering a “worldwide review of whether, and if so what, additional information would be 
27  needed from each foreign country to assess adequately whether their nationals seeking to enter the 
28  United States pose a security or safety threat.”  82 Fed. Reg. at 45161.  The Secretary of 

 
1  Homeland Security concluded from the review that “a small number of countries . . . remain 
2  deficient . . . with respect to their identity-management and information-sharing capabilities, 
3  protocols, and practices.”  Id.  To advance the “policy of the United States to take all necessary 
4  and appropriate steps to encourage foreign governments to improve their information-sharing and 
5  identity-management protocols and practices,” the President ordered a sharp curtailment, and in 
6  some cases a complete suspension, of entry into the United States by nationals of eight countries:  
7  Chad, Iran, Libya, North Korea, Syria, Venezuela, Yemen and Somalia.  Id. at 45162, 45165-67.   
8  The complaint focuses on Iran, Libya, Somalia, Syria and Yemen.  Dkt. No. 34 ¶ 4.1  For 
9  Iranian nationals, the President limited entry into the United States to holders of visas for students 
10  (F and M) or exchange visitors (J), and no others.  82 Fed. Reg. at 45165.  For Libyan nationals, 
11  the President suspended all immigrant entry, and nonimmigrant entry on business (B-1), tourist 
12  (B-2) and business/tourist (B-1/B-2) visas.  Id. at 45166.  For Somali nationals, the President 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  suspended all entry into the United States as immigrants, and required “additional scrutiny” of 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  nonimmigrant entry for ties to terrorist organizations or other threats to the United States.  Id. at 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  45167.  For nationals of Syria, entry as immigrants and nonimmigrants was suspended in toto.  Id. 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  at 45166.  For Yemeni nationals, entry as immigrants was suspended, as well as entry as 
S d nr
ee 17  nonimmigrants on business (B-1), tourist (B-2) and business/tourist (B-1/B-2) visas.  Id. at 45167. 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  The President also ordered the waiver program that is at the center of this dispute.  As 
19  Section 3(c) of the Proclamation provides, “a consular officer, or the Commissioner, United States 
20  Customs and Border Protection (CBP), or the Commissioner’s designee, as appropriate, may, in 
21  their discretion, grant waivers on a case-by-case basis . . . .”  82 Fed. Reg. at 45168.  “A waiver 
22  may be granted only if a foreign national demonstrates to the consular officer’s or CBP official’s 
23  satisfaction that:  (A) denying entry would cause the foreign national undue hardship; (B) entry 
24  would not pose a threat to the national security or public safety of the United States; and (C) entry 
25  would be in the national interest.”  Id. (Sec. 3(c)(i)).  
26 
27 
                                                 
1 The restrictions on nationals of Chad have been lifted.  Presidential Proclamation No. 9723, 83 
28 
Fed. Reg 15937 (Apr. 10, 2018).   
2 

 
1  The President directed the Secretary of State and the Secretary of Homeland Security to 
2  “coordinate to adopt guidance addressing the circumstances in which waivers may be appropriate 
3  for foreign nationals seeking entry as immigrants or nonimmigrants.”  Id. (Sec. 3(c)).  The 
4  Proclamation left the format of the guidance up to the agencies, but provided examples of 
5  circumstances when a waiver would be appropriate.  These situations included a foreign national 
6  who “seeks to enter the United States to visit or reside with a close family member (e.g., a spouse, 
7  child, or parent) who is a United States citizen, lawful permanent resident, or alien lawfully 
8  admitted on a valid nonimmigrant visa,” and for whom “the denial of entry would cause . . . undue 
9  hardship.”  Id. at 45169 (Sec. 3(iv)(D)).  They also included a “foreign national [who] seeks to 
10  enter the United States for significant business or professional obligations and the denial of entry 
11  would impair those obligations.”  Id. (Sec. 3(iv)(C)).   
12  A lawsuit brought in this circuit challenged the legality of the Proclamation, but the United 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  States Supreme Court upheld it as a proper exercise of the President’s discretion to suspend the 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  entry of aliens into the United States under Section 1182(f) of the Immigration and Nationality 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  Act.  Trump v. Hawaii, 138 S.Ct. 2392, 2408 (2018).  The plaintiffs had sought to enjoin the 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  Proclamation on the grounds, among others, that it was issued “for the unconstitutional purpose of 
S d nr
ee 17  excluding Muslims” in violation of the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment.  Id. at 2415.  
th
intr
Uo
N 18  The Supreme Court concluded that the plaintiffs were not likely to succeed on the merits.  The 
19  Court applied a rational basis review to find that “the entry policy is plausibly related to the 
20  Government’s stated objective to protect the country and improve vetting processes.”  Id. at 2420-
21  23.  The Court also assumed without deciding that the plaintiffs’ statutory claims could be heard 
22  notwithstanding the doctrine of consular nonreviewability.  Id. at 2407.   
23  The allowance for waivers in the Proclamation was an important reason why the five-
24  justice majority upheld it as serving a legitimate national security interest.  The majority cited the 
25  waiver program as one of “three additional features” of the President’s policy -- along with the 
26  subsequent removal of restrictions on three “Muslim-majority” countries and an allowance for 
27  “significant exceptions” for nonimmigrant entry -- that effectively dispelled concerns of religious 
28  animus or discrimination in the Proclamation.  Id. at 2422.  The majority put substantial emphasis 
3 

 
1  on the fact that DHS and the State Department were directed to “issue guidance elaborating upon 
2  the circumstances that would justify a waiver,” in the apparent expectation that this would 
3  establish a program similar to the “humanitarian exceptions” implemented by President Carter 
4  during the Iran hostage crisis.  Id.   
5  The four dissenting justices took a different view.  Most relevant here is Justice Breyer’s 
6  attention to the majority’s observations about the waiver program.  He suggested that, while the 
7  words might be reassuring, the incipient evidence available to the Court indicated that waivers 
8  were not being granted in practice.  At the least, this evidence raised a serious question about 
9  whether the program was mere “window dressing.”  Id. at 2432-33.  This matters because, if the 
10  government was not in fact actually administering the waiver program, “its argument for the 
11  Proclamation’s lawfulness becomes significantly weaker.”  Id. at 2430.

 sir
et
tatsiD 16  LEGAL STANDARDS 
S d nr
ee 17  The standards governing defendants’ motion to dismiss are well-established.  Rule 8(a)(2) 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure requires that a complaint must contain “a short and plain 
19  statement of the claim showing that the pleader is entitled to relief.”  To meet that rule and survive 
20  a Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss, a plaintiff must allege “enough facts to state a claim to relief 
21  that is plausible on its face.”  Bell Atl. Corp. v. Twombly, 550 U.S. 544, 570 (2007).  This does not 
22  impose a probability requirement at the pleading stage.  “[I]t simply calls for enough fact to raise a 
23  reasonable expectation that discovery will reveal evidence of” the conduct challenged by plaintiff.  
24  Id. at 556.  “A claim has facial plausibility when the plaintiff pleads factual content that allows the 
25  court to draw the reasonable inference that the defendant is liable for the misconduct alleged.”  
26  Ashcroft v. Iqbal, 556 U.S. 662, 678 (2009) (citing Twombly, 550 U.S. at 556).  In addition, the 
27  allegations in the complaint must be sufficiently clear and concrete to give the defendant an “idea 
28  [of] where to begin” in preparing a response to the complaint.  Twombly, 550 U.S. at 565 n.10.  
10 

 
1  Determining whether a complaint states a plausible claim for relief is a “context-specific task that 
2  requires the reviewing court to draw on its judicial experience and common sense.”  Iqbal, 556 
3  U.S. at 679. 
4  The Court will assume that plaintiffs’ factual allegations are true, and will draw all 
5  reasonable inferences in their favor.  Usher v. City of Los Angeles, 828 F.2d 556, 561 (9th Cir. 
6  1987).  But it will not “accept as true allegations that are merely conclusory, unwarranted 
7  deductions of fact, or unreasonable inferences.”  In re Gilead Scis. Sec. Litig., 536 F.3d 1049, 
8  1055 (9th Cir. 2008) (quotation omitted).  If the complaint is dismissed, an opportunity to amend 
9  will be provided unless the Court determines that no cure is possible by new allegations of fact.  
10  Lopez v. Smith, 203 F.3d 1122, 1130-31 (9th Cir. 2000).

3  II.  APA CLAIM 
4  The Administrative Procedure Act creates a “basic presumption of judicial review [for] one 
5  suffering legal wrong because of agency action.”  Weyerhaeuser Co. v. U.S. Fish and Wildlife 
6  Serv., 139 S.Ct. 361, 370 (2018) (alterations in original; quotation omitted).  Our circuit has 
7  construed the APA to provide for “broad judicial review of agency action:  ‘A person suffering 
8  legal wrong because of agency action, or adversely affected or aggrieved by agency action within 
9  the meaning of a relevant statute, is entitled to judicial review thereof.’”  Regents of the Univ. of 
10  Cal. v. U.S. Dep’t of Homeland Sec., 908 F.3d 476, 494 (9th Cir. 2018) (quoting 5 U.S.C. § 702).  
11  The APA also states that “[a]gency action made reviewable by statute and final agency action for 
12  which there is no other adequate remedy in a court are subject to judicial review.”  5 U.S.C. § 704.  
a 
tr in
uoro 13  Section 706 authorizes the reviewing court to “compel agency action unlawfully withheld” as well 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  as to set aside any agency action that is “arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, or otherwise 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  not in accordance with law.”  5 U.S.C. §§ 706(1) and (2)(A).   
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  Plaintiffs’ APA claim has solid legal support in the “well-established” proposition that 
S d nr
ee 17  “agencies may be required to abide by certain internal policies.”  Alcaraz v. Immigration and 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  Naturalization Serv., 384 F.3d 1150, 1162 (9th Cir. 2004).  This proposition was first recognized 
19  in United States ex rel. Accardi v. Shaughnessy, 347 U.S. 260 (1954), which involved an 
20  immigration dispute with overtones similar to this one.  The plaintiff in Accardi was an Italian 
21  immigrant who challenged the validity of a decision by the Board of Immigration Appeals 
22  (“BIA”) that denied his deportation appeal.  Id. at 262-63.  The Supreme Court reversed and 
23  ordered a new appeal hearing because the BIA had not acted in conformance with its governing 
24  regulations.  Those regulations required the BIA to exercise its own judgment and discretion when 
25  considering appeals, but the record indicated that the BIA had summarily denied Accardi’s appeal 
26  because he was on a list sent from the Attorney General of “unsavory characters” slated for 
27  deportation.  Id. at 264-67.  The Supreme Court concluded that the BIA’s decision was invalid 
28 
13 

 
1  because it had not, in fact, exercised its discretion as required by the regulations, but had instead 
2  allowed the Attorney General to dictate the result.  Id.   
3  The holding that administrative agencies are bound to follow their rules and guidelines has 
4  since been called the Accardi doctrine.  The Supreme Court reinvigorated the principle in Morton 
5  v. Ruiz, 415 U.S. 199, 235 (1974):  “Where the rights of individuals are affected, it is incumbent 
6  upon agencies to follow their own procedures.  This is so even where the internal procedures are 
7  possibly more rigorous than otherwise would be required.”  The doctrine applies to an agency’s 
8  procedures however they might be denominated.  See, e.g., Church of Scientology of Cal. v. 
9  United States, 920 F.2d 1481, 1487 (9th Cir. 1990) (“Pursuant to the Accardi doctrine, an 
10  administrative agency is required to adhere to its own internal operating procedures.”); see also 
11  Romeiro de Silva v. Smith, 773 F.2d 1021, 1025 (9th Cir. 1985) (noting that the INS can be bound

th
intr
Uo
N 18  Plaintiffs also allege claims under the Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution 
19  for substantive and procedural due process deprivations, and an equal protection violation.  Dkt. 
20  No. 34 ¶¶ 322-34.  The Fifth Amendment provides that “[n]o person shall be . . . deprived of life, 
21  liberty, or property, without due process of law.”   
22  For the due process claim, the threshold question is whether a plaintiff was deprived of any 
23  of these interests, because “no process is due if one is not deprived of ‘life, liberty, or property.’”  
24  Kerry v. Din, 135 S.Ct. 2128, 2132 (2015) (Scalia, J., plurality opinion) (quotation omitted, 
25  emphasis in original).  Plaintiffs do not directly allege such a deprivation, so the question is 
26  whether they were deprived of “certain implied ‘fundamental rights’” that are understood to be 
27  included under the “liberty” prong.  Id. at 2133.  This is also lacking.  Plaintiffs have not alleged 
28  any constitutionally protected fundamental rights for either the Family Member Class or the Visa 
16 

 
1  Applicant Class.  They refer to a “right” to the “integrity of the family unit,” but even assuming 
2  such a right can be found in the Fifth Amendment, which is not at all clear, plaintiffs concede that 
3  it would “not amount to a right of entry for foreign nationals, nor to an unfettered right to reside in 
4  the United States with family members who are foreign nationals.”  Dkt. No. 57 at 13.  Indeed, the 
5  Supreme Court has held in a plurality opinion that “[e]ven if we might ‘imply’ a liberty interest in 
6  marriage generally speaking, that must give way when there is a tradition denying the specific 
7  application of that general interest . . . .  Although immigration was effectively unregulated prior 
8  to 1875, as soon as Congress began legislating in this area it enacted a complicated web of 
9  regulations that erected serious impediments to a person’s ability to bring a spouse into the United 
10  States.”  Din, 135 S.Ct. at 2135.  Plaintiffs’ inability to allege a deprivation of an interest protected 
11  by the Due Process Clause means their claim must be dismissed in both its procedural and 
12  substantive iterations.  The dismissal is without prejudice and plaintiffs may amend, if they so

ee 17  497, 499-500 (1954); Buckley v. Valeo, 424 U.S. 1, 93 (1976).  Even so, there are problems with

N 18  plaintiffs’ equal protection claim.  Their claim is that the “waiver guidance that has issued has 
19  been arbitrary and capricious and designed to result in almost-uniform denials.  Taken as true, and 
20  given the background against which the waiver scheme arose, this supports an inference that the 
21  agency has a policy of denying waivers on discriminatory grounds, including nationality or 
22  religion.”  Dkt. No. 57 at 14.  This inference is not nearly as obvious as plaintiffs suggest, and 
23  demands assumptions unsupported by non-conclusory allegations of fact.  That will not do under 
24  Twombly and Iqbal.  See Iqbal, 556 U.S. at 768.  In addition, the logic that “almost-uniform 
25  denials” of waivers is tantamount to denial of “waivers on discriminatory grounds” holds together 
26  only if it is assumed that the Proclamation unconstitutionally excludes Muslims or illegally 
27  discriminates on the basis of nationality, a proposition that the Supreme Court turned aside in 
28  Hawaii.  138 S.Ct. at 2413-23.

12  duty.”  Heckler v. Ringer, 466 U.S. 602, 616-17 (1984).
